I just went through this with a new Dell Inspiron 6000 last week with SuSE 
9.2. I have a 80GB hard disk and there is a 4.4GB FAT32 partition and the 
rest of the disk was NTFS. I ran the SuSE installer and it was going to 
shrink down the size of the NTFS partition, create an extended partition 
where it would then create a swap and ReiserFS partitions for SuSE.

I didn't like that it was going to shrink down the NTFS partition to 15GB and 
so I did my own partitioning. In the end I ended up with an extended 
partitiom with a 1GB swap and 24GB ext3 partition. I haven't bothered looking 
yet to see what the 4.4GB FAT partition is that Dell creates. 

Could be some sort of recovery image. Dell provides an option on the XP Start 
menu that allowed to burn a recovery disk but I couldn't tell where it was 
grabbing the data for the CD image from. Unfortunately for compatibility with 
some people at work I need to keep XP around on my laptop although I'm 
booting it very infrequent after only a week.

In retrospect I should have created a small FAT32 partition to allow me share 
files with WinXP if needed. SuSE does mount my NTFS partition read-only and 
so I can access XP files. Only down side is if I wanted to change something 
under Linux I have no way to get it back to XP. 

I did manage to get the Intel 2915 WIFI and Intel 915GM graphics adapter 
running and so this laptop is working out quite nicely with Linux. My only 
grip with Linux is that is needs a better way to manage WIFI connections more 
like WinXP does. 

I've tried KWIFIManager under SuSE but it doesn't seem to be able to save any 
working profile information. I look out 
in /opt/kde3/share/apps/wifimanagerrcconfig and the file doesn't contain any 
of the WIFI information I entered through the KWIFIManager config panel. It's 
not a big deal since I really only need it for WEP protected networks.

For accessing WPA protected networks I use the "wpa_supplicant" daemon. It has 
it's own configuration file and will go through my list of networks in its 
configuration file and automatically create an association between my laptop 
and an access point. It can supposedly handle WEP as well but apparently the 
Intel "ipw2200" has a few issues still which keeps WEP from working with the 
"wpa_supplicant" daemon.  If I need to use WEP I use the network 
configuration screen in "YaST2" to setup the SSID and encryption keys for a 
WEP network.

Tony

Regards the Firefox logo drawn on the center of the OSU quad:

> I am a little surprised they didn't get rousted by Campus Security.

I went to OSU, and the campus police were "legendary".   They were
often the target of practical jokes, and the particular focus of the
residents of second-floor Weatherford, known as the "Nads". 

For example, the time that the Nads stole the water fountain from the
Corvallis police department, and left it in the corner of the outer office
of the Campus police - where it stayed, unconnected and nonfunctional, for
months, as the Kops waited for Facilities to connect it (the little
"Property of the City of Corvallis" tag apparently exceeded their reading
abilities).

Their police radios never worked.  They always ended up with blown
transmitters.  One of the Nads had this pesky habit of reaching up inside
the fender to the antenna mount with a length of wire and alligator clips,
shorting the whip to the fender.  The shorting wire would typically fall off
as they sped back to the Kop Shop to report their dead radio.  They never
figured this out.  Perhaps the tradition continues today.

The snow-covered "volkswagon" stalled on the railroad tracks running through
campus during a snowstorm was a nice touch.  When a westbound freight came
through campus (yes, the main freight tracks ran through the campus), the
Kampus Kops called for an emergency stop of the locomotive, while they
pondered how to move the stalled vehicle off the tracks.  The Nads solved
the problem, by running out to kick the volkswagon-shaped snow sculpture to
pieces.

That was 30 years ago.  Last year we were at OSU to watch the human powered
vehicle race at DaVinci days.  The race went west down Campus Way, a narrow
street that necks down to one lane in places. 
A brilliant Kampus Kop decided to watch the oncoming race with her Kop Kar
blocking the lane,  so the oncoming vehicles had to divert over curbs and
onto the sidewalk to avoid collisions.


So I do not believe that OSU Campus Security would be capable of detecting
the existence of students painting the quad at night. And if the cops did
somehow manage to notice, they could easily be neutralized with donut-laden
mousetraps, or phony job offers from the Department of Homeland Security.

Quoth Kurt Sussman, on Mon, 9 May 2005 13:15:44 -0700:

> I use ext2 for the boot partition and reiserfs for everything else.
> I've been doing this for over 6 years and I've had zero problems.
> Yeah, ext3 has more recovery modes, but most of the recovery CDs can
> handle reiserfs and I haven't needed them (recovery CDs) for
> filesystem problems, so why mess with success?

One reason is, if I'm not mistaken, ext3 is a "journaling" file system,
whereas ext2 is not.  So there's less chance of corruption, and if you
should ever crash, ext3 will not have to scan your partition when you
reboot.

> I have an old Compaq notebook with a 6G drive, and it runs XP Pro just
> fine. So I might just reserve 7G for Windog and make one partition
> FAT32 so it can be used from both Linux and XP.

That'd be my way.  I'd allocate a little less for the main Win' part',
though, just enough for the core OS and maybe a few app's.  Then make
that FAT part' bigger, and install Windose app's on it as needed.  This
way, if you never use much Win' software, you won't have much wasted
space that you can't access from Linux.

Message-ID: <428018D7.20808@cesmail.net>

I'll vote for ext3 over Reiserfs for two reasons:

1. Partition Magic supports ext3
2. Parted supports ext3

There are hacked/patched versions of "parted" and its libraries that
pretend to support Reiserfs. That way lies file corruption. Sure, you're
going to back stuff up before you re-partition, but why waste the extra
time?

>>I use ext2 for the boot partition and reiserfs for everything else.
>>I've been doing this for over 6 years and I've had zero problems.
>>Yeah, ext3 has more recovery modes, but most of the recovery CDs can
>>handle reiserfs and I haven't needed them (recovery CDs) for

> 
> One reason is, if I'm not mistaken, ext3 is a "journaling" file system,

ReiserFS is also a journaling file system, along with jfs and xfs.  In 
some circumstances (which I can't remember off the top of my head right 
now) ReiserFS performs better than ext3, but not in a manner that you 
will be able to notice on a laptop hard drive.

I believe up until recently ReiserFS didn't support the extended 
attributes used by SELinux, so I don't know if SuSE Pro 9.3 has a 
version that supports it.  However, if memory serves me, SuSE doesn't 
ship with SELinux turned on anyway.

Jason

John -

> And there is (as I feared) a problem with the video. It should be 
> running at 1280 x 800. Instead it is 1024 x 768, vesa. I right-clicked 
> on the desktop and went into settings, but that's the only resolution 
> option. I think I remember someone here or in the R3000 e-list 
> saying that he had a problem with the ATI Radeon Xpress 200 and 
> how he resolved it. I'll research that later.

I am not familiar with ATI cards, since I'm an Nvidia guy, but my laptop 
has an 1280x800 display, and it is not supported by the standard X 
configuration tools (I run FC3).  The only distro I've used that 
detected and configured it right the first time was Ubuntu.  I would 
suggest Googling for something like "Radeon 1280x800 xorg.conf" and look 
for people who have set it up.  It will probably involve hand editing 
your /etc/X11/xorg.conf file, though perhaps Yast is better at adding 
custom stuff than Fedora's tools.

> Sound is working. And I put a symphony CD in the drive and it 
> popped up KsCD and started playing it. However, there is a 
> problem with the volume. With the volume control in KsCD and the 
> volume control on the system tray both at 100%, it is about one 
> quarter as loud as it should be for normal listening. I'm not sure 
> what is wrong. Also, I paused the play, but it doesn't stay paused. 
> It goes back to playing after a few minutes. I tried the Stop button 
> instead, but when I click on Play it goes back to the beginning 
> instead of resuming. Night be a KsCD problem.

Modern linux distributions use the Advanced Linux Sound Architecture 
(ALSA) for sound, which has separate mixer settings for a whole bunch of 
stuff, including CD and PCM (MP3/OGG/whatever digital audio).  Open the 
volume control and look for the CD mixer, it's probably set way low.

Hope that helps, perhaps someone more familiar with SuSE and KDE can 
chime in a bit.

Jason


From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue May 10 02:32:31 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 10 May 2005 02:32:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why I like Lisp
Message-ID: <861x8ftoi8.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


I recently found myself needing to compute the results of the Bessel
Function of the First Kind, Order Zero, J(0,x), for a series of
x-values with precision at least equal to that reported in the classic
tome _Handbook of Mathematical Functions_ (Abramowitz and Stegun) in
Table 9.1, which is 15 decimal places.

I was able to write the bessel function in 8 lines of Common Lisp.
Furthermore, in byte-compiled CLISP exact results took only twice as
long as a native-code compiled C "approximate" method that became
numerically unstable one third of the way through the range I was
interested in (x from 0 to 100 by 0.1).

Let me see another language do as well.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From rich at paranoid.org  Tue May 10 09:29:23 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 09:29:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] It's Here!!
In-Reply-To: <428078F9.7338.57DED4D@localhost>
References: <427F96AA.24358.209E7DA@localhost>
	<428078F9.7338.57DED4D@localhost>
Message-ID: <37407.192.65.17.24.1115742563.squirrel@o4.hostbaby.com>

On Tue, May 10, 2005 9:03 am, John Jordan said:
> Last night I was chatting on IRC with a Linux guru. He wanted me
> to find the xorg.conf file, but it's not on this computer. Also, a lot of
> the bash commands he told me to use did not work. "Locate" and
> "slocate" just gave me "unknown command."

It's possible that locate and slocate are not there. They just may not
have been chosen to be installed. I can't believe SUSE would not have a
version of one of them available somehow.

They may also be there but not in your PATH.

If you can't get to one of them you can always use the "find" command. It
searches the filesystem live, so it's slower that locate, but it's also
more accurate. If you add or remove files on the filesystem, locate will
not see them until its database is updated.

> He also wanted me
> to find the XF86Config file. Using the GUI file finder I finally found it.
> But when I opened it, it turned out to be a binary file.

You may have been looking at a symbolic link to the actual file. If you go
to that directory in a shell (not through the GUI) and do an "ls -l", you
will see where the symlink points to.


Rich

I went through this when I manually upgraded SuSE 9.2 to X.org 6.8.2 packages 
so I could get the Intel 915GM adapter working on my Dell Inspiron 6000. I 
use "Sax2" to configure X and it modifies /etc/X11/XF86Config but the new 
X.org packages I installed look at /etc/X11/xorg.conf instead. It took me a 
few tries to figure out why my changes were not being picked up when they 
looked great in the Sax2 preview screen.

My workaround was to make a symbolic link named /etc/X11/xorg.conf that points 
to /etc/X11/XF86Config.

The latest version of Mandrake (what would have been 10.2), known as Mandriva 
2005LE does support it. Current stuff for LCDs is: 1024x768, 1280x1024, 
1280x800, 1400x1050, 1440x900 (which is what I run), 1600x1200, 1680x1050, 
1920x1200, 640x480, and 800x600. Something for everyone.

You can download ISOs or use bittorrents by joining the MandrivaClub (various 
levels, ranging from free to expensive - I've been a Silver Club level for 
years) at: http://www.mandrivaclub.com/

I just gave a copy of the latest Mandriva disks to someone who had never tried 
Linux before and they said that it was easier to set up than Windows. Good 
stuff.

From ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net  Tue May 10 11:51:23 2005
From: ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 11:51:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Reinstall?
In-Reply-To: <42809E57.20798.60FE25A@localhost>
References: <4280476D.9080802@verizon.net> <42809E57.20798.60FE25A@localhost>
Message-ID: <200505101151.23433.ewilhelm@sbcglobal.net>

# The following was supposedly scribed by
# John Jordan
# on Tuesday 10 May 2005 11:43 am:

>I think I'm going to have to wipe out Suse 9.3 and reinstall. It's the
>only way I can think of to get it out of my data partition and into
> the partition I want it in.

The only way?  Why not just move or copy the files (then edit 
your /etc/fstab) to make it the way you want it?  This could be tricky 
if you're new, but post some details and the list can tell you how to 
do it.

Basically, you just need to understand the way *nix sees the filesystem 
as one tree with devices mounted on it.  Once everything is mounted, it 
doesn't matter which device the stuff is on.

In particular, your current /etc/fstab would be good to see.

--Eric

> And how do I get rid of Suse? Parts of it are in the small partition

Many linux installers provide options for selecting which partitions
should be formatted upon installation.  So you should be able to just
pop in an install CD and redo/reformat your partitions as needed during
installation.

On Tuesday 10 May 2005 11:43 am, John Jordan wrote:
> Before I forget, is there a file manager that shows the partition you
> are looking at? Every time I use Konqueror it just shows folders. I
> have no idea where I am. You know the old file manager that came
> with Windows 3.0 and 3.1? Something like that, showing all the
> partitions and their folders in a tree-like text-only window (suffering
> from icon overload here).

I just got home from having root canal and I'm not really too with it, so 
please bear that in mind.

I am not aware of any file browser that shows which partition the current 
directory is in (anyone else know of one?), but that is sort of antithetical 
of the nature of *nix. The original idea of Unix that is pretty much still 
the case in Linux (and other Unii) is that /everything/ is a file. When Sun 
shared NFS (Network File System) with the world back in the early 80's, that 
allowed it to use the marketing slogan, "The network is the computer." And 
having to be aware of "where" you are, whether its which partition you are on 
or which computer you are on at gets in the way of the goal of portable code.

> And while I'm on that subject, I need some education about the
> different folders. Like /etc, /usr, and so on. I understand the need
> for short names back in the days when everything had to be typed,
> but I have no idea what those folders mean or what is supposed to
> be in them. Or where I am supposed to install programs. Or where
> my own data files are supposed to go. Is there a beginner's intro to
> Linux folder conventions somewhere? Something I could print out
> and tape up on the wall here would be handy.

Yes indeedy do! Please go to The Linux Documentation Project 
(http://www.tldp.org/) and read away. Another wonderful resource is The Linux 
Tutorial (http://www.linux-tutorial.info/) that should answer many of your 
questions.

And there is this list, PLUG, which is filled with many wonderful people who 
are anxious to help. Some of them have been doing Linux for so long, they 
have forgotten that newbies don't always know all of the acronyms. Be patient 
with them (us) and they (we) will be patient with you.

> I think I'm going to have to wipe out Suse 9.3 and reinstall. It's the
> only way I can think of to get it out of my data partition and into the
> partition I want it in. And, considering my current frustration with
> Suse 9.3, I'm open to suggestions for something else. I have
> Fedora Core 3 here on DVD and CD with the Sam's "unleashed"
> book I got down at Powell's. But if Mandriva will recognize the
> Radeon Xpress 200 and set it up at 1280 x 800 like it is supposed
> to be, maybe that would be a better choice.

Well, I have used many of the different distros (I won't bother enumerating 
them) and I end up always coming back to Mandrake for my laptop machines. 
When it comes to running a server, I personally think Debian is a better 
choice, but for desktops and /especially/ laptops, Mandrake, er, Mandriva is 
the Bomb.

BTW, the reason that Mandriva gives for the name change is that they merged 
with Connectiva, the largest South American distro and so they combined the 
names (Mandrake is based in France). The real reason is that the comic 
syndicate that owns the rights to the Mandrake the Magician comic strip sued 
them to stop using the name. Tacky.

> And how do I get rid of Suse? Parts of it are in the small partition it
> was supposed to be in, but I think it's just empty folders in there.
> The rest is in the big partition. Should I just format them both? I
> know Windows would scream bloody murder if you tried to format
> the drive it's on -- you have to do it from a boot floppy with format or
> fdisk or something.

When you install Mandrake, the (very nice) partition manager will do that work 
for you.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 10 18:09:42 2005

On Tue, 10 May 2005, John Jordan wrote:
> And while I'm on that subject, I need some education about the different 
> folders. Like /etc, /usr, and so on. I understand the need for short 
> names back in the days when everything had to be typed, but I have no 
> idea what those folders mean or what is supposed to be in them. Or where 
> I am supposed to install programs. Or where my own data files are 
> supposed to go. Is there a beginner's intro to Linux folder conventions 
> somewhere? Something I could print out and tape up on the wall here 
> would be handy.

There's a nice page or two on the subject in Essential System 
Administration.  If you don't have that, you should get it and read it... 
twice.  At least read it once now and again in six or eight months after 
you've been doing things your way for a while and have some of your own 
mental constructs in place.

Your own data files are all in /home and that's mostly where they belong. 
I personally keep a /usr/local/public where data files are stored that 
everyone's going to access (like music and movies).

The way I run things, I never ever touch anything but /home, /usr/local, 
and /etc (and only there to modify configuration files).  Everything else, 
I sacrifice to St. Debian.  I build software in /usr/local/src for 
installation in /usr/local... etc.

And at some point or another, everything needs to be typed.

J.

Joshua

vi is present even on the minimal Gentoo *install* CD when you boot up.
Once you chroot and start working in your Gentoo install, it' s not
there any more, even in a stage3 install. When I do a stage3 install,
the first thing I do in the install script that runs at chroot time is
install vi off of the package CD. :) But yeah, it ought to be in the
stage3 tarball if it's on the boot CD.

> http://www.wihatools.com/716_IPR_serie.htm

I'm unsure about those actually being Torx. The Torx security bits are
the Torx shaped screws with the post in the center. These in turn need a
Torx bit with the end drilled out.

> I'd actually like to reuse the case, but I'm getting so frustrated that 
> the hacksaw is starting to sound like a good idea. Grr.

Merely need to hacksaw/drill the screws, and then the case can be kept.

> The general public isn't allowed to buy these bits (see: "Tamper 
> resistant"). Does anyone on the list have access to these buggers? I'd 
> love to borrow them for an evening to perform the laptop <---> 
> enclosure HD swap. I suspect that upon return, your bits or 
> screwdrivers might come with tasty, tasty beer as well.

One source is EBay. Locally Norvac has some types of security bits. They
had a set with the drilled-Torx and tri-wing bits. I'm unsure about them
having the five-pointed bit you're looking at.

On Mon, 2005-05-09 at 22:36 -0700, Jason R. Martin wrote:
> >>I use ext2 for the boot partition and reiserfs for everything else.
> >>I've been doing this for over 6 years and I've had zero problems.
> >>Yeah, ext3 has more recovery modes, but most of the recovery CDs can
> >>handle reiserfs and I haven't needed them (recovery CDs) for
> >>filesystem problems, so why mess with success?
> > 
> > 
> > One reason is, if I'm not mistaken, ext3 is a "journaling" file system,
> > whereas ext2 is not.  So there's less chance of corruption, and if you
> > should ever crash, ext3 will not have to scan your partition when you
> > reboot.
> 
> ReiserFS is also a journaling file system, along with jfs and xfs.  In 
> some circumstances (which I can't remember off the top of my head right 
> now) ReiserFS performs better than ext3, but not in a manner that you 
> will be able to notice on a laptop hard drive.
> 
> I believe up until recently ReiserFS didn't support the extended 
> attributes used by SELinux, so I don't know if SuSE Pro 9.3 has a 
> version that supports it.  However, if memory serves me, SuSE doesn't 
> ship with SELinux turned on anyway.
> 
> Jason

Reiser performs better for LOTS of small files, XFS performs better for
VERY large files, ext3 holds the middle ground of performance.  Here's
some numbers from a brief google search for filesystem benchmarking...

           reiser4   reiserfs       ext3        XFS        JFS

copy     33.39,34%  39.55,32%  39.42,25%  43.50,32%  48.15,20%

sync      1.54, 0%   3.15, 1%   9.05, 0%   2.08, 1%   3.05, 1%

recopy1  31.09,34%  75.15,13%  79.96, 9% 102.37,12% 108.39, 5%

recopy2  33.15,33%  77.62,13%  98.84, 7% 108.00,12% 114.96, 5%

sync      2.89, 3%   3.84, 1%   8.15, 0%   2.40, 2%   3.86, 0%

du        2.05,42%   2.46,21%   3.31,11%   3.73,32%   2.42,17%

delete    7.41,52%   5.22,58%   3.71,39%   8.75,56%  15.33, 7%

tar      52.25,25%  90.83,12%  74.93,13% 157.61, 7% 135.86, 6%

sync      6.77, 2%   4.19, 3%   1.67, 1%   0.95, 1%  38.18, 0%

overall 171.28,30% 302.53,16% 319.71,11% 429.79,13% 470.88, 6%

As you can see Reiser4 is the fastest by far and XFS the next to slowest. 
However if you change the test criteria to include very large files,
then XFS will start showing better times.

Add here's an article with enough graphs to make you dizzy, this one checks 
a large number of common tasks against several file systems.
http://linuxgazette.net/102/piszcz.html

From publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com  Wed May 11 13:55:11 2005
From: publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com (Ovid)
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 13:55:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DNS issues
Message-ID: <20050511205511.80485.qmail@web60819.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi all,

When I first set up my DSL through Earthlink, I discovered that my DNS
resolution was very, very slow.  Earthlink wouldn't help me because I
was running FC2.  A friend sent me a list of nameserver IP addresses to
 add to my /etc/resolv.conf and that fixed the problem.

Today, the problem is back with a vengeance (at least, I assume  it's
DNS related).  I can surf and when I finally get to a page it loads
quickly and when I hit refresh it reloads quickly.  It's that initial
lag which is killing me.

How the heck do I diagnose issues like this?  More importantly, any
pointers on fixing them?

My iBook is running on the same network and it's not having any
problems.  (It's going through the wireless router which in turn is
connected to the Netopia DSL modem.  The FC2 box is connected directly
to the Netopia DSL modem).

Cheers,
Ovid

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Wed May 11 14:15:45 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 15:15:45 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] DNS issues
In-Reply-To: <20050511205511.80485.qmail@web60819.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050511205511.80485.qmail@web60819.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae05051114155de5538c@mail.gmail.com>

try doing a traceroute, ping -c1, and a 'host google.com $DNSSERVER a
bunch of times in a loop.

For instance, to see if you've got an intermittent latency issue, do 

for i in `seq 1 1000` ; do host google.com 155.101.246.110 ; done

and doing it with a ping, and traceroute will start to indicate if it
is an issue with response time of BIND on the server (or whatever it's
running), latency in the network, etc.

/eli

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed May 11 14:40:32 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 14:40:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DNS issues
In-Reply-To: <20050511205511.80485.qmail@web60819.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050511205511.80485.qmail@web60819.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <42827BD0.6090607@madboa.com>

On 5/11/05 1:55 PM, Ovid wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> When I first set up my DSL through Earthlink, I discovered that my DNS
> resolution was very, very slow.  Earthlink wouldn't help me because I
> was running FC2.  A friend sent me a list of nameserver IP addresses to
>  add to my /etc/resolv.conf and that fixed the problem.

You might try disabling IPv6; that seems to do it for some:

echo "alias ipv6 off" >> /etc/modules.conf

I don't know if a reboot is necessary, but you almost certainly have to 
restart networking: /etc/init.d/network restart

> How the heck do I diagnose issues like this?  More importantly, any
> pointers on fixing them?

strace and tcpdump are your two biggest friends when an application is 
misbehaving. In this case, the tcpdump solution might provide more 
interesting feedback.

In xterm #1, do (as root)

   tcpdump port 53

In xterm #2, do

   dig www.pdxlinux.org

The console spew will tell you what servers your resolver library is 
trying to use; the timestamps will tell you where the delay is happening 
(if you can't spot it during the run).

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

Jason Van Cleve (jason at vancleve.com) typed this ...
> Quoth Kurt Sussman, on Mon, 9 May 2005 13:15:44 -0700:
> 
> > I use ext2 for the boot partition and reiserfs for everything else.
> > I've been doing this for over 6 years and I've had zero problems.
> > Yeah, ext3 has more recovery modes, but most of the recovery CDs can
> > handle reiserfs and I haven't needed them (recovery CDs) for
> > filesystem problems, so why mess with success?
> 
> One reason is, if I'm not mistaken, ext3 is a "journaling" file system,
> whereas ext2 is not.  So there's less chance of corruption, and if you
> should ever crash, ext3 will not have to scan your partition when you
> reboot.

OK, to clarify what I wrote, I was talking about reiserfs as the
'success' part. In fact, I just formatted the root and boot partitions
on my new HD with ext3.

I have to say, though, that I've never experienced a reiserfs failure
(though I've heard about a lot of them). I have, unfortunately,
experienced an ext3 failure. This is obviously too small a data set to
reach any conclusions, but it has affected my choice of filesystems in
the past. I'm giving ext3 a try now, but I'm also keeping regular
backups.

> > I have an old Compaq notebook with a 6G drive, and it runs XP Pro just
> > fine. So I might just reserve 7G for Windog and make one partition
> > FAT32 so it can be used from both Linux and XP.
> 
> That'd be my way.  I'd allocate a little less for the main Win' part',
> though, just enough for the core OS and maybe a few app's.  Then make
> that FAT part' bigger, and install Windose app's on it as needed.  This
> way, if you never use much Win' software, you won't have much wasted
> space that you can't access from Linux.

I expect that this will be the way I go. But I'm still doing some
research into my Windows-execution options.

Thanks.

--Kurt

you're not running either of those (or servers in general).

From rich at paranoid.org  Wed May 11 15:32:18 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 15:32:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] DNS issues
In-Reply-To: <20050511213827.68638.qmail@web60818.mail.yahoo.com>
References: 6667 <20050511213827.68638.qmail@web60818.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <59319.192.65.17.24.1115850738.squirrel@o4.hostbaby.com>

On Wed, May 11, 2005 2:38 pm, Ovid said:
> Thanks.  The "host google.com $DNSSERVER" always seems to return
> immediately as does the "ping -c1 google.com".  However, the traceroute
> on both my iBook and the FC2 box does this (from the Ibook):
>
> 13  vlan201-msr1.dcn.yahoo.com (216.115.96.163)  116.508 ms  134.078 ms
> vlan221-msr2.dcn.yahoo.com (216.115.96.167)  118.578 ms
> 14  ge2-2.bas2-m.dcn.yahoo.com (216.109.120.153)  137.382 ms
> ge3-1.bas2-m.dcn.yahoo.com (216.109.120.146)  178.671 ms
> ge6-1.bas2-m.dcn.yahoo.com (216.109.120.221)  104.433 ms
> 15  * * *
> 16  * * *

It sounds like you have your problem resolved, but FYI, traceroutes are
unfortunately less useful than they used to be. In the old days you could
traceroute pretty much anywhere, but now many people filter ICMP at their
firewalls/routers. They do it to prevent ICMP DoS attacks, and also to
prevent people from gaining more information about their networks.

Traceroute is still pretty handy for looking at things like the path you
are taking through your ISP and then the Internet backbone, but once you
get to the network on the other end it may not tell you much more (which
seems to be what's happening in the example above).


Rich

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu May 12 06:28:48 2005
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Tony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 08:28:48 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] How to burn an ISO image
In-Reply-To: <42828E4A.2508.DA13241@localhost>
References: <42828E4A.2508.DA13241@localhost>
Message-ID: <200505120828.48371.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Thursday 12 May 2005 00:59, John Jordan wrote:
> OK, I'm stupid, and this is slightly off-topic. I downloaded Ubuntu
> live CD ISO image and am trying to use it to boot my new Compaq
> R4000 (the AMD64 Live Image CD at
> http://us.releases.ubuntu.com/releases/5.04/).
>

Under SuSE 9.x there's a KDE-based CD/DVD burning tool called "K3b". You can 
find it off of the main menu panel off of the KDE panel. Look inside the 
"Multimedia" menu. Once you have "K3b" running simply go to:

Tools->CD->Burn CD Image... 

A popup dialog will appear and you can select the ISO image file to burn to a 
CD. I'm assuming that SuSE has been able to correctly detect your CD-RW drive 
on your R4000 for this to work.

Regards,

Tony

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

Are both your keyboard and mouse USB?  If so, it might just be the
udev config barfing on it.  Try setting the "Legacy USB Mode" (or
something similar) in your BIOS just to test it.  Of course, if they
are both USB and you can get into the BIOS, it is already enabled...
n/m

Can you get to a virtual console in the installer by pressing
ctrl-alt-F1 (through F6)?

/eli

OK, there is definitely something screwy with the way Linux wants 
to treat the keyboard on this thing. I just downloaded and burned 
the live ISO for Knoppix 3.8 (thanks to Steven for pointing me in the 
right direction). I stuck the CD in the drive and restarted the 
compute. It worked *much* better than Ubuntu. Has a prettier 
screen than Suse, too. :)

It went ahead and automatically installed itself all the way, from the 
CD without installing to the hard disk. After it was fully running I 
clicked around on things and then I noticed the clock was wrong, 
so I went to adjust the time. Tried to enter my password, and the 
keyboard wouldn't work. Opened OpenOffice.org Writer and again, 
no keyboard. 

Also the touchpad is dead (worked under Suse 9.3), although my 
external Logitech USB wireless optical mouse is working fine. And 
the display just came up at VESA 1024 x 768. At least Knoppix 
lists two other options, 800 x 600 and 640 x 480, but still no 1280 
x 800. Screen display is faster under Knoppix, though. And the 
display is much more attractive -- 3D effects and shadows on icons 
and stuff.

I have no wireless here at home, so yesterday I took it to a friend's 
house. Her laptop was seeing her wireless fine, but when I booted 
Suse the wireless was dead. I just went into Knoppix network 
setup and clicked on "Wavelan." After a moment or two it popped 
up a message "no wireless card detected." So that's another 
problem I have to work on.

I kind of like Knoppix from what I am seeing -- at meast much more 
than Suse, which, after three days of it had become seriously 
annoying. Later this afternoon I think I'll install it in a new partition 
and then maybe I will play around with stuff to see if I can fix these 
problems.

Thanks for the suggestions!

From ckonstan at lunarlogic.com  Thu May 12 11:44:12 2005
From: ckonstan at lunarlogic.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 11:44:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Installing Knoppix
In-Reply-To: <20050512112030.48f9f1d3.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050512112030.48f9f1d3.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0505121134210.7089@localhost>

Yes.  Boot under a knoppix CD (either in text or gui mode).  Then get a
shell and type "knx2hd".  This launches the installer.

Before you do this, fdisk your hard drive the way you want it and mke2fs
and mkswap as necessary.

Start the installer and go through the "configure setup".  Then choose
"save config".  Save the config to an easy-to-find spot.  Then exit the
installer and edit the file to suit your needs.  The installer does not
give you access to all the config options, which is why you want to do
this.

Then restart the instaler with "knx2hd" and choose "load config".  Load
your config, then immediately commence the installation.

You do not get to select packages.  You get what knoppix gives you,
period.  Once knoppix is up on your rooy filesystem, you want to apt-get
away everything but fluxbox and emacs (just my opinion).

Also, you'll want a revised sources.list:


deb file:/var/cache/apt-build/repository apt-build main
# See sources.list(5) for more information, especialy
# Remember that you can only use http, ftp or file URIs
# CDROMs are managed through the apt-cdrom tool.

# Security updates for "stable"
deb http://security.debian.org stable/updates main contrib non-free
deb http://security.debian.org testing/updates main contrib non-free

# Stable
deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian stable main contrib non-free
deb http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian-non-US stable/non-US main contrib non-free
# deb http://ftp2.de.debian.org/debian-non-US stable/non-US main contrib non-free

# Sources
# deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/pub/debian stable main contrib non-free
# deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/pub/debian-non-US stable/non-US main contrib non-free

# Testing
deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian testing main contrib non-free
deb http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian-non-US testing/non-US main contrib non-free
# deb http://ftp2.de.debian.org/debian-non-US testing/non-US main contrib non-free

# Sources
# deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/pub/debian testing main contrib non-free
# deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/pub/debian-non-US testing/non-US main contrib non-free

# Unstable

  real    3m15.429s
  user    0m0.070s
  sys     0m0.070s

That works out to an average just over 5/second.

Hi folks,

When a retail ISP who buys bandwidth from someone like ELI has a 10MBit
connection, and they are operating at near capacity, e.g. 9700 kbps,
would that cause major latency (e.g. like 300 ms) at that retail ISP's
gateway to ELI?

For example, see the first graph at:

http://tercent.com/~rlucas/serial5-0-day.png

During times where that graph is almost at the "red" line, would that
indicate times where ping times might get throttled down from a usual
~80 ms to 300 ms+?

I'm trying more fully to understand how this issue might come about,
rather than bugging the ISP prematurely.  I don't know how these
agreements are usually strucutred (e.g. does the ELI-type player
typically let the extra traffic through but then bill, or slow down
traffic, or drop packets, or ???).

Likely, since whatever you're using to graph that utilization probably
does something like 5 minute averages. In the course of those five
minute periods, you're probably getting spikes that hit 100% of whatever
ceiling is imposed, and packets are dropped.

> I'm trying more fully to understand how this issue might come about,
> rather than bugging the ISP prematurely.  I don't know how these
> agreements are usually strucutred (e.g. does the ELI-type player
> typically let the extra traffic through but then bill, or slow down
> traffic, or drop packets, or ???).

Could be any of those strategies, and it will depend on what you've
purchased and what they've actually configured. Check your contract...

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Thu May 12 15:13:34 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 16:13:34 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Network latency and percent usage practices.
In-Reply-To: <4283BC5C.1040308@tercent.com>
References: <4283BC5C.1040308@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae0505121513141344df@mail.gmail.com>

I'm not honestly sure how it would be affected by the router (whatever
is rate-limiting/QoS your connection). When this occurs in an
host-to-host TCP connection, and you hit the ceiling and drop/delay a
packet due to congestion the "old" way of Linux handling it was to cut
back your send rate by 50% immediately, and slowly scale up.

Newer kernels with TCP_BIC (2.6.8 and newer) use a smarter algorithm
that slowly scales back from peak until you stop congestion/start
getting ACK's in sync again with your transmit rate.

I don't have enough experience with the hardware in the middle to say
what its response to hitting your subscribed bandwidth cap would be. 
Even if the qos logic was just 'holding' an ACK to throttle it down,
if the hosts didn't respond nicely you could fesably have your
bandwidth drop, then creep back up (same behaviour described above).

One way to see is to check (during off-peak hours) by increasing the
granularity of your traffic graphing, and do a point to point iPerf to
an off-site host, and see what happens.

/eli

From baloo at ursine.ca  Thu May 12 17:49:03 2005
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 17:49:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast ARP behavior question
In-Reply-To: <a4fbdc7b05051209594a6b97b3@mail.gmail.com>
References: <42837BBE.3080800@mail.mesd.k12.or.us>
	<a4fbdc7b05051209594a6b97b3@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200505121749.03497.baloo@ursine.ca>

On Thursday May 12 2005 9:59 am, Fedor Pikus wrote:

> Seems a bit too much, but not by an order of magnitude. I get them
> at a rate of about 20 per second, perhaps. Cable network is weird
> in this regard: it's not routed, because you can see everyone's arp
> traffic, but not simply bridged either because you can't see
> everyone's ip traffic.

You're seeing the difference between segementation and broadcast 
domains there.  It's not weird, it's actually fairly common.  You'll 
see this anytime the broadcast domain is larger than the network 
segment you're on.  It doesn't mean the network isn't routed (as it 
most certainly is).

-- 
Paul Johnson

This depends on the tech you get when you call Comcast.  The vast
majority will help regardless of OS, though a couple times I've had to
say "tell me what you'd do in Windows and I'll do the equivalent thing
on my Linux box".  A sizable minority of the techs are actually
interested in what the equivalent is on Linux.  A tiny minority refuse
to help at all on non-Windows-- call back and get someone else.

However, they always say "we only really support Windows" and if the
problem gets tricky they may pull that card.

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Thu May 12 20:32:37 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 20:32:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Installing Knoppix
In-Reply-To: <86oebgl1w3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050512112030.48f9f1d3.jason@vancleve.com>
	<86oebgl1w3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <42841FD5.6080700@cesmail.net>

What "actually" happened is that Knoppix has some differences in the
packages it requires and their dependencies from the stock Debian
repositories. As a result, if you blindly sync your system with Debian,
it deletes things you need to have. There are ways to fix this, but if
you want a mix of Sarge and Sid (or Etch and Sid in the not-too-distant
future) you're better off installing Sarge directly to your hard disk
and keeping Knoppix as a "rescue disk".



Russell Senior wrote:

>Don't take this as definitive, because I am not sure what *actually*
>happened, but the time I did an HD install of Knoppix and then did a
>few apt-get upgrades over the course of a week or two, it got wedged
>pretty severely.  After that, I figured if I was going to install (and
>I had the bandwidth available) I might as well just do a straight
>Debian net-install which is a pretty easy, one-time thing.
>
>
>  
>

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu May 12 21:51:20 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 21:51:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix hangs
Message-ID: <20050513045120.GA18400@gate.kl-ic.com>


I have postfix running on my vcolo gateway machine, processing about
12 mails (or spam attempts) per minute.  The machine is backed up over
the network at 430AM or so, saturating the bandwidth between that
machine and my site.   About once a week, during backup time, postfix
decides to hang and stop moving mail, leaving it queued up on the
vcolo machine rather than pushing it to the mail server on my site.
A "service postfix restart" causes the mail to start moving again.
I would like to figure out why, but there are no clues in 
/var/log/maillog or /var/log/messages on either machine (and the
maillog file runs to 20K+ lines due to all the spam,  so even 
hunting through it can take a long time).

The easiest way to resolve this is to automatically do the postfix
restart after the backup completes, but this seems awfully sloppy. 
Is there a clean way to jiggle postfix to remind it to keep working,
or else to figure out what is making postfix hang up so I can fix
the real problem?

Keith

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu May 12 22:33:09 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 22:33:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Postfix hangs
In-Reply-To: <20050513045120.GA18400@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Thu, 2005-05-12 at 21:51 -0700, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> I have postfix running on my vcolo gateway machine, processing about
> 12 mails (or spam attempts) per minute.  The machine is backed up over
> the network at 430AM or so, saturating the bandwidth between that
> machine and my site.   About once a week, during backup time, postfix
> decides to hang and stop moving mail, leaving it queued up on the
> vcolo machine rather than pushing it to the mail server on my site.
> A "service postfix restart" causes the mail to start moving again.
> I would like to figure out why, but there are no clues in 
> /var/log/maillog or /var/log/messages on either machine (and the
> maillog file runs to 20K+ lines due to all the spam,  so even 
> hunting through it can take a long time).
> 
> The easiest way to resolve this is to automatically do the postfix
> restart after the backup completes, but this seems awfully sloppy. 
> Is there a clean way to jiggle postfix to remind it to keep working,
> or else to figure out what is making postfix hang up so I can fix
> the real problem?

I think there are thresholds past which Postfix will stop processing and
accepting incoming mail, in an attempt to prevent it from breaking the
host.  I cannot think of what those are right now, but you might try
just using 'postqueue -f' to make it try to start delivering again.

(Also, you might try use greylisting and Postgrey to cut back on your
spam flood :)

Wil

From rich at paranoid.org  Fri May 13 07:58:44 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)

On Thu, May 12, 2005 11:11 pm, Robert Anderson said:
> What does `/sbin/route` say? Sounds like you might not have a default
> gateway defined. But if ssh and https work, that might not be the
> case.

Yeah, it's odd. It sounds like it would be a routing issue, but that
doesn't fit with him being able to access other services.

I can suggest a couple of possible things to try:

1) Try the "telnet thatbox 8080" from on the box itself, if your packet
filtering rules should allow that. Then you can at least make sure the
server is accepting connections on that port.

2) Do some packet sniffing (tcpdump, ethereal, whatever). I would sniff on
the Tomcat box while you try to connect in, and then maybe sniff on the
other end, too.

None of this is a fix, just more data to troubleshoot with.

You might also try disabling your packet filtering briefly and test. I
know you said you checked over the iptables stuff and that it looked good,
but we all are capable of overlooking things.

Except maybe Wil.

;)


Rich

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri May 13 08:05:41 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 09:05:41 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Mandriva Installation
In-Reply-To: <42845C8C.14786.14AEE402@localhost>
References: <42845C8C.14786.14AEE402@localhost>
Message-ID: <f4468cae05051308055181c1a5@mail.gmail.com>

If you got to the grub prompt, you're not TOO bad off.

At this point, provided the install DID properly set up your
partitions and copy files to your root, you just need to:

1) Find out what partition your /boot or /root are on.
   If you remember, great, if not boot with /K|G/noppix, and do an
'fdisk -l /dev/hda' (provided you have an IDE drive, and you installed
to the primary master.)

2) You need to tell grub to intall itself back to the boot sector
(which it already did properly), and give it a device to point at for
its config (/boot/grub/menu.lst, and others).
   The drive addressing in GRUB SUCKS, for some reason the developers
decided to use a non-standard reference for labeling
drives/partitions.  If you installed your /boot or / onto /dev/hda1,
grub calls this (hd0,0), and if it's on /dev/hda3 (hd0,2).

Here I'll give you a quick, maybe partially correct command set.
Provided your /boot directory (or / if you don't have one) is on
/dev/hda2

in the grub shell:

root (hd0,1)

setup (hd0)

quit

Rebooting (should) get you into your boot menu for the system,
provided the layout you gave it is correct, and there are no other
problems.

/eli

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Fri May 13 09:30:18 2005
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 09:30:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DocBook
Message-ID: <4284D61A.6090702@axpr.net>

I know we have at least a few published authors here... so I thought I'd
check and see - what did you guys use to create your books?

I'm involved with a project that's using DocBook to create a book... an
online manual of sorts.  It was being built in to HTML/PDF/PS/whatever
on a FreeBSD box using a BSD Make-based toolchain.  However, as we're
migrating the project to a Linux box, this is no longer an option.

So, I went looking for how to do this.  The book is written in SGML with
each chapter having its own directory, generally with a single file in
the directory (chapter.sgml), in the "root" directory, there's
book.sgml, authors.sgml, glossary.sgml, a .dsl file, and various logos
and such.

It would seem to me, with as popular a format as it seems DocBook is,
there would be an *easy* way to take this layout and convert it to a
PDF, single-page HTML, and multi-page HTML tree.

Looking around, however, it seems there is not.  Does anybody know why
not?  And has anybody here home-grown something that might work or be
adaptable and useful by the community at large?

It just seems so odd there isn't some well documented simple way of
dealing with DocBook trees like this.  :-\

Rob

Quoting Ronald Chmara <ron at Opus1.COM>:

> 
> On May 6, 2005, at 9:10 PM, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Paul Johnson wrote:
> >> On Friday May 6 2005 3:34 pm, AthlonRob wrote:
> >>> Paul Johnson wrote:
> >>>> It's generally safe to block sites that don't have a PTR.
> >>> I disagree... although I realize in the war on spam, there will be
> >>> some innocent bystanders killed.
> >> Very, very few.  Even if the PTR isn't correct (as is the case for
> >> me), it at least exists for almost every assigned IP out there.
> > I seem to see more and more PTRs vanishing by the day from broadband
> > users.  :-\
> 
> I saw a Very Large (listed on NASDAQ, something like 30 global 
> locations) data center company wipe them out for hundreds of customers 
> once (while switching their DNS over). Not good at all. Took months and 
> months to sort it all out, because they switched over to a DNS server 
> which required a fairly non-bind-friendly implementation.
> 
> Getting back to the original matter, I'd use a missing PTR as a 
> *weighting* factor of spam, if I was worried about losing any valid 
> email. *Especially* if incoming email is expected from clients (or 
> whatever) running off of DSL/Cable/etc. from less experienced ISPs, or 
> coming from companies whose DNS admins are possibly in need of 
> additional training.
> 
> -Bop

Spam control will be easier if access to proper 
indentification is improved for all people who have mail 
servers on the Internet.  Proper identification is one
area where I feel strongly that new laws may be 
appropriate.  My first thought is enacting a law 
requiring ISP's to ensure that there is a valid 
PTR record for every single one of their Internet 
connected customers.  A second law could bar ISP's 
from charging extra to their customers to ensure that 
this PTR record exists and is valid.

As far as blocking people in the event they make a typo,
my blocks are temporary at first.  If you're trying to
get a hold of me, you shouldn't make a typo entering the
address.

Without secure and complete domain registration, there 
won't be any easy solutions to the spam problem as far 
as I can tell.  Trusting any rule for smtp style email 
servers, such and such exchanger should be used first, 
seems arbitrary considering that everyone is supposed 
to have a PTR record.  Even if greylisting would not 
block major and commonly valid email sources including 
AOL, I'd be very much impressed.  If you can't affectively
filter email based on where it's coming from, you're in
trouble as far as I'm concerned.

     --  Michael Robinson

On Thu, 12 May 2005, Reid Leake wrote:

> I have freed another HD of dreaded NTFS, and want to use it (well a
> partition on it) as my /home directory. I added this to my /etc/fstab:
>
> /dev/hdb1       /home     reiser4 notail,noatime     0     0

> Is there anything else I need to do besides move my files from the
> old /home to the new partition (hdb1) to make this transition?

Reid,

   The entry in /etc/fstab does two things: 1) allows for automounts during
reboots and 2) allows root to mount the new filesystem manually.

   What I suggest you do is a four-step process[1]:

   1.  'mv /home /home-old' # this prevents having two filesystems with the
 				same name but mounted at different points.

   2.	(as root) 'mount /dev/hdb1 /home'

   3.  (as you) 'cd /home; cp -a /home-old/* .' # copy all from old to new.

   4.	'rm -rf /home-old/*' # Once you're sure everything is where it should
 				be.

   Then you can do as you wish with the home-old/, including rmdir.

HTH,

Rich

PLUGgers will let you know, and let me have it for being clueless and

From ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net  Fri May 13 10:26:30 2005
From: ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 10:26:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving /home directory
In-Reply-To: <1115959479.8700.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20050513012725.C0D1844B5@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<1115959479.8700.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200505131026.30678.ewilhelm@sbcglobal.net>

# The following was supposedly scribed by
# Reid Leake
# on Thursday 12 May 2005 09:44 pm:

>Is there anything else I need to do besides move my files from the
>old /home to the new partition (hdb1) to make this transition?
>If so, this sure is easier than certain 'other' OSes.
>I am running Ubuntu, which is Debian based, if that makes a
> difference.

The way *nix sees the filesystem is as one single tree, which means that 
you can do all sorts of crazy (and even stupid) things with your mount 
points and everything will work exactly the same.

The one tricky bit here would be the copy/move operation onto a mount 
point.  You probably don't have any hidden files directly under /home/, 
but if you did, you would have to use the cp as shown below to get them 
all in one blow.

mkdir /mnt/disk
mount /dev/hdb1 /mnt/disk
# 'mv /home/* /mnt/disk/' misses hidden files
cp -a /home/./  /mnt/disk/
cd /
# got backups?
# rm /home/ -rf
# ^-- that assumes that home is not currently a mount point
mkdir /home/
umount /mnt/disk
mount /home

Heck, you don't even have to delete everything that's under /home to 
mount on top of it (unless you wanted that disk space back :-)

Now.  Does anyone know of an mv command which is equivalent to the above 
copy?  That is, moves everything from *within* a directory to another 
(including hidden files.)

--Eric

On 5/13/05, AthlonRob <athlonrob at axpr.net> wrote:
> I know we have at least a few published authors here... so I thought I'd
> check and see - what did you guys use to create your books?
> 
> I'm involved with a project that's using DocBook to create a book... an
> online manual of sorts.  It was being built in to HTML/PDF/PS/whatever
> on a FreeBSD box using a BSD Make-based toolchain.  However, as we're
> migrating the project to a Linux box, this is no longer an option.
> 
> So, I went looking for how to do this.  The book is written in SGML with
> each chapter having its own directory, generally with a single file in
> the directory (chapter.sgml), in the "root" directory, there's
> book.sgml, authors.sgml, glossary.sgml, a .dsl file, and various logos
> and such.
> 
> It would seem to me, with as popular a format as it seems DocBook is,
> there would be an *easy* way to take this layout and convert it to a
> PDF, single-page HTML, and multi-page HTML tree.
> 
> Looking around, however, it seems there is not.  Does anybody know why
> not?  And has anybody here home-grown something that might work or be
> adaptable and useful by the community at large?
> 
> It just seems so odd there isn't some well documented simple way of
> dealing with DocBook trees like this.  :-\
> 

There is the docbook-tools software from RedHat, 
http://sources.redhat.com/docbook-tools/.  It is packaged as
docbook-utils.  It can convert to PDF and lots of other formats.  As
long as there is a single master .sgml file which includes the others,
and a .dsl stylesheet you want to use, it works just fine.

 - Ian

On Fri, 2005-05-13 at 09:49 -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:

>    My understanding is that DocBook is great for technical manauals that will
> be "published" primarily on the web.

I don't think so.  O'Reilly sponsored the development of DocBook as an
open format for their own publications (I'm pretty sure; I cannot find a
reference on the DocBook site or O'Reilly).  It's fairly straightforward
to take DocBook sources and generate HTML, PDF, PS and to endlessly
tweak the resulting formats with style-sheets.

In an attempt to answer to Rob's question (although I am not a published
author): You can use SYSTEM entities to break a document up into
multiple files.  I'm not entirely sure if that's what you're asking
about or how that works with SGML instead of XML, but I think it should
be similar.  For an XML example, see:

http://haus.nakedape.cc/svn/public/trunk/writing/Defending-Email-HOWTO/Defending-Email-HOWTO.xml

While we're on the topic of DocBook, Paul Heinlein was going to send me
some examples of customizing headers and footers of generated HTML with
XSLT or DSSSL.  Paul?

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri May 13 11:39:35 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 11:39:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] DocBook
In-Reply-To: <4284E00F.8080101@axpr.net>
References: <4284D61A.6090702@axpr.net> <4284E00F.8080101@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <4284F467.7050002@madboa.com>

On 5/13/05 10:12 AM, AthlonRob wrote:

> I've discovered SGML hasn't been actively developed since '02 or so, and
> XML toolchains to do the job exist and are fairly common now.
> 
> So, I guess it's time to go through the ~30,000 lines of SGML and
> convert it to XML.  Uhhh.. yay.

[Note: I frist sent this message a hour ago, but DNS woes plaguing the 
comcast.net domain have kept it bottled up until now.]

Beyond the simple joy of migrating from SGML to XML, you also get the
blissful task of choosing which DocBook schema you want to use (DTD or
RelaxNG) and which version you want (4.{1,2,3} or 5.0).

I keep all my personal files in DTD 4.3, but many distro packages aren't
there yet, so you may end up using an earlier version or rolling your
own package to bring it up to date.

The tea leaves scattered around my floor suggest that RelaxNG is the
coming thing, but I frankly haven't worked up the energy to research the
issue.

I'd be happy to discuss (on- or off-list) the toolchain I've developed,
which includes custom XSL templates, Makefiles, HTML Tidy, xsltproc,
xmllint, and fop -- but pretty it's not...

If PDF output is a high priority for you, make sure you're aware of what
FO processing features you need before settling on a tool. Apache fop
works fine for me, but the current release version (0.25) is dated and
somewhat limited.

Finally, it's definitely worth perusing Bob Stayton's book on DocBook
XSL processing: http://www.sagehill.net/docbookxsl/. Don't leave /home
without it. :-)

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

>

> compilation?  This is using gcc-3.3.2, by the way.

Possible answers:

  1. Use gcc-3.4. (I just tried the above and it produced an error).

  2. Compile with "-Werror".  Will turn all warnings (including that one)
     into errors.

  3. use "#define" rather than "const int" (local non-pointer constants
     seem a little silly to me...)

  4. there might be another command-line option, but since I can't get
     gcc-3.4 to take that code at all, I don't know what it might be.

On 5/13/05 1:48 PM, Matt Alexander wrote:

> alert admins of problems. I've also heard of Nagios and Zabbix and I'm

I use nagios 2.0b2 to monitor 38 services on 23 hosts/devices. The 
initial setup was a bit hairy, but it's worked well since then. My local 
setup has two limitations; they aren't limitations in nagios, only in 
the amount of time I've put into the project:

1. I've currently only got it doing e-mail notifications since I don't
    yet have a modem attached to the monitoring server.

2. I haven't set up user accounts so that admins responsible for certain
    hosts can login and setup downtimes, mark problems as known, etc.

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri May 13 15:19:16 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 15:19:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Moving /home directory
In-Reply-To: <20050513183947.A052743F1@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200505132219.j4DMJGaG025572@m5p.com>

>From: Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
>    The entry in /etc/fstab does two things: 1) allows for automounts during
> reboots and 2) allows root to mount the new filesystem manually.
> 
>    What I suggest you do is a four-step process[1]:
> 
>    1.  'mv /home /home-old' # this prevents having two filesystems with the
>  				same name but mounted at different points.
> 
>    2.	(as root) 'mount /dev/hdb1 /home'

Trivial, but crucial missing step here; mkdir /home.

>    3.  (as you) 'cd /home; cp -a /home-old/* .' # copy all from old to new.
> 
>    4.	'rm -rf /home-old/*' # Once you're sure everything is where it should
>  				be.
> 
>    Then you can do as you wish with the home-old/, including rmdir.

Exceedingly bad idea to the move this way. I must *strongly* recommend
using dump/restore for this. For which the commands would be:

cd /home; dump -0f - /home | restore -xf -

The one issue is you need an appropriate FS-specific dump program for
your root FS (the lack of which is a fatal weakness of ReiserFS for me)
for this to work. Failing that `tar` will work in most circumstances.

The key point is that dump and to a lesser extent tar will preserve
interesting things on the filesystem. Notably cp *will* *not* handle
links correctly! Nor will cp preserve the various timestamps. GNU tar is
decent at preserving those, as well as other interesting extras on the
filesystem. OTOH dump/restore will guarentee preservation of links.


--

> cd /home; dump -0f - /home | restore -xf -
>
> The one issue is you need an appropriate FS-specific dump program for
> your root FS (the lack of which is a fatal weakness of ReiserFS for  
> me)
> for this to work. Failing that `tar` will work in most circumstances.
>
> The key point is that dump and to a lesser extent tar will preserve
> interesting things on the filesystem. Notably cp *will* *not* handle
> links correctly! Nor will cp preserve the various timestamps. GNU  
> tar is
> decent at preserving those, as well as other interesting extras on the
> filesystem. OTOH dump/restore will guarentee preservation of links.
>

The gnu cp on most Linux systems has the "-a" flag that preserves  
links, modes, permissions and timestamps, so on Linux cp can handle  
links correctly.  However, the cp on most other Unix variants I use  
don't have the -a flag, including to my surprise Mac OSX.

I personally think rsync is the best option, since it preserves  
links, modes, permissions and time stamps and it makes it possible to  
stop and resume later.

mkdir /newhome
rsync -av /home/ /newhome



From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri May 13 16:55:59 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 17:55:59 -0600

Nagios rox!

As a long-term user, I'm happy.  Upgrading to 2b drastically reduced
monitoring system load.  After getting nrpe compiled and configured
(non-standard installations), I've got a setup monitoring 500+ HPC
nodes, and dozens of separate fileservers/enterprise service systems,
etc with no headaches.

Just take your time with layout in the beginning, and you'll save
yourself serious time and money in the long-haul.  FYI, anything that
can be somehow checked on the command line can be scripted with
Bash/Perl as a plugin.

/eli

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri May 13 16:51:33 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 17:51:33 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Moving /home directory
In-Reply-To: <200505132219.j4DMJGaG025572@m5p.com>
References: <20050513183947.A052743F1@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<200505132219.j4DMJGaG025572@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae05051316515a198d53@mail.gmail.com>

cp -a DOES keep our niceties intact like links, timestamps etc:

CP(1)                     User Commands                     CP(1)
       -a, --archive
              same as -dpR
       -d     same as --no-dereference --preserve=link
       --no-dereference
              never follow symbolic links
       -p     same as --preserve=mode,ownership,timestamps
       -R, -r, --recursive
              copy directories recursively

Though you may sometimes see the timestamp on the NEW symlink as that
when it was copied (always seems like a bug to me).

There are lots of ways to accomplish everything in *NIX, but I'm
personally a fan of the simplest.  Just as you can pipe a tar/untar
through an SSH session, I prefer to just use rsync -e ssh

:)

/eli

On 5/13/05, Elliott Mitchell <ehem at m5p.com> wrote:
> >From: Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
> >    The entry in /etc/fstab does two things: 1) allows for automounts during
> > reboots and 2) allows root to mount the new filesystem manually.
> >
> >    What I suggest you do is a four-step process[1]:
> >
> >    1.  'mv /home /home-old' # this prevents having two filesystems with the
> >                               same name but mounted at different points.
> >
> >    2. (as root) 'mount /dev/hdb1 /home'
> 
> Trivial, but crucial missing step here; mkdir /home.
> 
> >    3.  (as you) 'cd /home; cp -a /home-old/* .' # copy all from old to new.
> >
> >    4. 'rm -rf /home-old/*' # Once you're sure everything is where it should
> >                               be.
> >
> >    Then you can do as you wish with the home-old/, including rmdir.
>

>

>

> your root FS (the lack of which is a fatal weakness of ReiserFS for me)

: After reading what you said I wonder what I have. I thought it was

There is no such thing as 10.1 LE.  There is just 10.1 which came out
a few months ago.  10.2 was due out in April.  Then Mandrake merged
with Connectiva, changed their name, and changed their product cycle.

The new schedule has them introducing a new version every year around
October.  The first one will be called "Mandriva 2006" coming out this
October 2005.  But because we were all on the cust of 10.2 they decided
to release a "limited edition" 2005:  not limited in functionality, but
only in availability---no boxed set, only download.

: but everything I can find on the computer says it is 2005

Look in /etc/mandrake-release.  That tells all.
Also, if uname -r returns "2.6.11-6mdk" or "2.6.11-6mdksmp"
and you have not updated your kernel, then you are running 2005LE (or
is it LE2005? I can never remember!)

Correct.  Anyway, if you really have 10.1, I have 2005LE on DVD.
We can talk about this offline if you like.

: Does anyone know how to contact Mandriva? There is a phone 
: number on their website, but it is a message phone only. It's hard 
: for me to be called back because some days I'm in class almost 
: all day long. 

Mandriva is located in Paris, France.  Besides they won't help you
w/o paying them $$.

However the mandriva "experts" mailing list is just about the best
e-mail discussion list I've ever seen and I've been doing lists for 20
years.  The SNR is very high.

The archives for the Mandriva lists are here:

<http://archives.mandrakelinux.com/>

You want either "newbie" or "expert" in English.  Don't worry about
the "expert" title. That just means some of the people on the list are
experts.  But there are plenty of semi-Newbies as well.  Nobody will
yell at you if you ask a beginner question, as long as you have tried
first to figure it out for yourself.

To sign up and start participating go to 

<http://www.linux-mandrake.com/en/flists.php3>

and sign up for expert and/or newbie.
Pay no attention to the "purchase support" advertisement.
Just get on the mailing lists and you'll find help.

: Couldn't find an e-mail address. I want to ask them if 
: their regular for-pay version has drivers for the ATI Radeon Xpress 
: 200M video chip. The reason I want to ask them is because during 
: the installation of this LE version there was a screen saying that it 
: was LE so I wouldn't get proprietary drivers for Nvidia and ATI.

Not sure what that message said.  But here's the deal:
If you are an "ordinary" non-paying user then the download that is
available to you contains none of the commercial drivers and various
other stuff that they prepare for paying customers.  

All that stuff is, in fact available to you.  You just have to go to
the vendor sites yourself and download what you need. Also, it won't
(necessarily) be packaged as a nice Mandriva .rpm.

On the other hand, if you purchase the dist. (which you can't do with
2005LE since they are not selling it boxed) then you get an additional
couple of CDs with all this stuff in one place, and packaged in mandrake
.rpm's that have been tested to install properly.

A third option (the one I use) is to purchase "Mandriva Club"
membership which entitles members to all these additional packages
plus some other privileges.  I do this mainly to support Mandriva because
I like the dist.

Again the "proprietary drivers for Nvidia and ATI" are all available
from the vendors over the web.  Talk with me offline and I may be able
to help you.

Dean

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri May 13 19:56:18 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 19:56:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Moving /home directory
In-Reply-To: <20050514013151.0173C4478@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200505140256.j4E2uIED028396@m5p.com>

>From: Dwight Hubbard <dwight at dwightandamy.com>
> > Exceedingly bad idea to the move this way. I must *strongly* recommend
> > using dump/restore for this. For which the commands would be:
> >
> > cd /home; dump -0f - /home | restore -xf -
> >
> > The one issue is you need an appropriate FS-specific dump program for
> > your root FS (the lack of which is a fatal weakness of ReiserFS for  
> > me)
> > for this to work. Failing that `tar` will work in most circumstances.
> >
> > The key point is that dump and to a lesser extent tar will preserve
> > interesting things on the filesystem. Notably cp *will* *not* handle
> > links correctly! Nor will cp preserve the various timestamps. GNU  
> > tar is
> > decent at preserving those, as well as other interesting extras on the
> > filesystem. OTOH dump/restore will guarentee preservation of links.
> 
> The gnu cp on most Linux systems has the "-a" flag that preserves  
> links, modes, permissions and timestamps, so on Linux cp can handle  
> links correctly.  However, the cp on most other Unix variants I use  
> don't have the -a flag, including to my surprise Mac OSX.

I'm aware of the capabilites of cp, I still stand by my point *DO*NOT*
use cp for moving significant slices of filesystems around! Most Unix
flavors -pR is sufficient, GNU is the only one that needs an additional
option for maximal preservation.

Of note I said "links", not "symbolic links". cp *will*not* handle hard
links correctly. GNU tar will only _probably_ handle them correctly. For
illustrative purposes, a portion of my home directory on PSU's CS
systems:

$ ls -lin
total 1972
    307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4  2004 -f
    307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4  2004 -fr
    307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4  2004 -r
    307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4  2004 -rf
<...>

$ du -sk *
32      -f
32      -fr
32      -r
32      -rf
<...>

There are plenty of other strange things people can and *will* do on home
directories. cp won't correctly replicate this. GNU tar will likely
successfully replicate something roughly equivalent this, after burning
processor time for *hours*, and the result may not fit on a single modern
disk. By contrast, dump/restore *will* replicate this perfectly in less
than a second, and the result will be less than a megabyte.

Disk moves are best accomplished by tools designed for that. dump/restore
beat everything else, because they'll replicate everything (in addition
to the above, they'll also handle ACLs, flags and other interesting FS
features, such as lsattr/chattr on ext2). tar will get the most crucial
bits of structure, but it is a very poor second compared to dump/restore.
cp isn't even close to vaguely adequate for this purpose.

Just in case anyone is curious, I'm pretty sure home directories at PSU's
CS department are backed up with dump.  :-)

> I personally think rsync is the best option, since it preserves  
> links, modes, permissions and time stamps and it makes it possible to  
> stop and resume later.
> 
> mkdir /newhome
> rsync -av /home/ /newhome

rsync can handle hard links and sparse files, but it won't do so with
anywhere near the efficiency of dump though. Not to mention you still
lose filesystem features as with tar.

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri May 13 21:32:43 2005
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 22:32:43 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Moving /home directory
In-Reply-To: <200505140256.j4E2uIED028396@m5p.com>
References: <20050514013151.0173C4478@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<200505140256.j4E2uIED028396@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae050513213211b40a73@mail.gmail.com>

OT at this point, but it make me wonder about an issue with some
weirdness in RHEL4-AS installs... if anyone has a box around that they
haven't already fixed, I'd be curious to know the answer....

If you're running AS4 (and probably ES and WS), try and copy
/var/lastlog anywhere.  Or use rsync, or tar... you'll end up with an
endlessly growing monstrosity (or a copy that never ends, but doesn't
get any bigger).  For some reason, the install barfs on the file, an
it ends up with a flaky inode;  taking the system down and mounting it
with a rescue/knoppix disk and fscking it results in _always_ a single
fixed inode, and the ability to then safely
backup/move/delete/whatever /var/log/lastlog.

I noticed that when arkeia backups were having these enormous backup
sizes, with a file that had around 3000% compression ratio!

Anyhow, I'd be interested if somehow dump handles this (admittedly
corrupt) situation differently.

/eli

From dwight at dwightandamy.com  Fri May 13 23:56:58 2005

On May 13, 2005, at 9:56 PM, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
>
> I'm aware of the capabilites of cp, I still stand by my point *DO*NOT*
> use cp for moving significant slices of filesystems around! Most Unix
> flavors -pR is sufficient, GNU is the only one that needs an  
> additional
> option for maximal preservation.
>
> Of note I said "links", not "symbolic links". cp *will*not* handle  
> hard
> links correctly. GNU tar will only _probably_ handle them  
> correctly. For
> illustrative purposes, a portion of my home directory on PSU's CS
> systems:
>
> $ ls -lin
> total 1972
>     307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4   
> 2004 -f
>     307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4   
> 2004 -fr
>     307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4   
> 2004 -r
>     307209 -rw-r--r--   4 1831     300      1099511627775 Aug  4   
> 2004 -rf
> <...>
>
> $ du -sk *
> 32      -f
> 32      -fr
> 32      -r
> 32      -rf
> <...>
>

Under GNU cp, hard links are copied too:
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> dd if=/dev/random of=testfile bs=1k count=2
0+2 records in
0+2 records out
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> ln testfile testfile2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> ls -i
91573 testfile  91573 testfile2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> mkdir testdir2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> cp -a testfile* testdir2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> cd testdir2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir/testdir2> ls -i
91579 testfile  91579 testfile2

And on modern distributions it also copies ACLs

dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> setfacl -m u:dhubbard:r testfile
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> getfacl testfile
# file: testfile
# owner: dhubbard
# group: users
user::rw-
user:dhubbard:r--
group::r--
mask::r--
other::r--

dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> cp -a testfile* testdir2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir> cd testdir2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir/testdir2> ls -la
total 8
drwxr-xr-x  2 dhubbard users 104 2005-05-14 01:01 .
drwxr-xr-x  3 dhubbard users 128 2005-05-14 00:46 ..
-rw-r--r--+ 2 dhubbard users 170 2005-05-14 00:46 testfile
-rw-r--r--+ 2 dhubbard users 170 2005-05-14 00:46 testfile2
dhubbard at linux:/tmp/testdir/testdir2> getfacl testfile
# file: testfile
# owner: dhubbard
# group: users
user::rw-
user:dhubbard:r--
group::r--
mask::r--
other::r--

It also works between filesystems types, like say between reiserfs  
and ext3, dump/restore don't.

> There are plenty of other strange things people can and *will* do  
> on home
> directories. cp won't correctly replicate this. GNU tar will likely
> successfully replicate something roughly equivalent this, after  
> burning
> processor time for *hours*, and the result may not fit on a single  
> modern
> disk. By contrast, dump/restore *will* replicate this perfectly in  
> less
> than a second, and the result will be less than a megabyte.

Yes tar is one of the least efficient ways of moving data I have used.

> Disk moves are best accomplished by tools designed for that. dump/ 
> restore
> beat everything else, because they'll replicate everything (in  
> addition
> to the above, they'll also handle ACLs, flags and other interesting FS
> features, such as lsattr/chattr on ext2). tar will get the most  
> crucial
> bits of structure, but it is a very poor second compared to dump/ 
> restore.
> cp isn't even close to vaguely adequate for this purpose.

That is a good point, cp certainly doesn't copy the filesystem  
attributes and probably never will.   I'll have to play with these a  
bit :-)

> Just in case anyone is curious, I'm pretty sure home directories at  
> PSU's
> CS department are backed up with dump.  :-)
>
>
>> I personally think rsync is the best option, since it preserves
>> links, modes, permissions and time stamps and it makes it possible to
>> stop and resume later.
>>
>> mkdir /newhome
>> rsync -av /home/ /newhome
>>
>
> rsync can handle hard links and sparse files, but it won't do so with
> anywhere near the efficiency of dump though. Not to mention you still
> lose filesystem features as with tar.

The only thing rsync doesn't handle are the file attributes, current  
versions of rsync support softlinks, hardlinks, sparse files, and  
acls just like gnu cp.

Rsync is really useful when the user home directory is very large and  
you want to keep the downtime to a minimum, because you can rsync it  
once to get the bulk of the data over to the new location.  Then when  
you are ready to do the switch, run the rsync again.  That second  
rsync is a hell of a lot faster than a dump unless there are a huge  
amount of changes.

Of course the main reason I don't use dump/restore is because they  
don't exist for reiserfs which I'm running on my Linux boxes.
