On Wednesday May 18 2005 10:46 am, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth John Jason Jordan, on Wed, 18 May 2005 01:56:34 -0700:
> > stupid. OK, maybe I am. I'm trying to learn Linux, but it's going
> > to take me a long time. In the meantime I'm going to have to take
> > some
>
> That is the beginning of wisdom.  Anyone who tells you that
> learning linux is not a whole lot of work is a bald-faced liar.

OK, I'm calling your bluff.  It's not *that* hard to learn, especially 
these days.  You have free support at just a google or an email away, 
and as many second opinions as you need in the same place.  Unix just 
has some fundamental differences from the Microsoft approach that 
take getting used to if you have only been exposed to the Microsoft 
approach.  Once you get over that mental hurdle, the rest really just 
falls into place.

That being said, if you're handy on MacOS X, you won't be at a loss 
here, just be extra careful until you get used to the differences in 
UI, particularly with command flags while you're getting adjusted.
 
> You seem to want to really understand things, and so for you there
> will be cursing, pulling of hair, weeping and gnashing of teeth. 
> (Was it any different to learn Winders?)

Well, I only spent about a year going through fits learning Linux, 
took me half a decade to get the Microsoft approach down, and I was 
exposed to that first.  I was able to pick up Linux and now consider 
myself considerably more proficient in Linux than Windows.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu May 19 07:53:18 2005
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 07:53:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Using K3b to Kreate Koasters
In-Reply-To: <428C3F3E.26509.2494A88@localhost>
References: <428C3F3E.26509.2494A88@localhost>
Message-ID: <428CA85E.4020704@dimstar.net>

John Jordan wrote:

>Right now I have K3b open and the three files that I 
>downloaded from MandrivaClub are listed in DataDVD3 window as 
>a K3b Data Project:
>
>Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.iso
>Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.md5.asc
>Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.sha1.asc
>  
>

Putting them in a project just burns the files to a data disk.

You need to "Burn image to disk".

This is under the "Tools>DVD>Burn Image" menu option. When you open 
that, you then select the iso file, and burn only that image. The other 
two files are not part of the iso, they are verification files.

http://java.sun.com/products/java-media/jmf/2.1.1/jmfdiagnostics.html

When it loads, I get the error message:

JMF classes.....Not Found

Following Sun's instructions, I set the following environment variables from 
the terminal (I've also exported them in my .profile file):

JMFHOME=/home/someuser/JMF2.1.1
CLASSPATH=$JMFHOME/lib/jmf.jar:$JMFHOME/lib/sound.jar:.:${CLASSPATH}
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$JMFHOME/lib:${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}

I don't understand the last part of the last two variables, the part that 
encloses the variable I'm setting in a pair of braces. When I look at the 
variables with echo, I get this:

> echo $CLASSPATH
/home/rsteff/JMF2.1.1/lib/jmf.jar:/home/rsteff/JMF2.1.1/lib/sound.jar:.:
> echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH
/home/rsteff/JMF2.1.1/lib:

I assume I should be getting something after the trailing : and that this is 
why the diagnostic page tells me it can't find the CLASSPATH.

The troubleshooting information on the diagnostic page says:

Classes not found: JMF classes are not included in the CLASSPATH environment 
variable. Please make sure the CLASSPATH points to jmf.jar that comes with 
your installation.

jmf.jar is found in /home/rsteff/JMF-2.1.1e/lib

Any ideas?

Okay, are you sure you are entering the path to the file itself? For example:

/home/username/myfile.iso

The other files you don't need to worry about. the md5 and sha1 files are just 
there so you can do a checksum on the ISO image to ensure you have the real 
ISO. In fact, K3B will create the md5 checksum as soon as you put the path 
for the ISO in.

- Chris

John Jordan wrote:

>OK, I tried that. I have the ISO file above in the Burn ISO9660 
>Image window, in the Image to Burn box. But down below it says 
>No Image File Selected and the Start button is grayed out.
>  
>
If the file is valid, it will show the information for the image. Valid 
or not, this will include an MD5sum that you can compare to that md5.asc 
file you have.

It sounds like you didn't get a complete file.

What are the contents of the md5.asc and sha1.asc files? You should have 
a checksum in each. You can get an md5sum on the iso file with the 
following command:

#md5sum Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.iso

This will result in a string of numbers and letters with the filename 
after it. Compare this string to the contents of the md5.asc file. If 
they don't match, you don't have a valid file. Depending on how you 
downloaded the file, you may be able to recover, or you may have to 
download the whole file again.

>Previously I used Nautilus to do something that made an ISO 
>image on disk, which I thought included all three files. When I put 
>this image in the Image to Burn box it shows down below a filesize 
>of 366 Kb and an Md5 Sum, among other things.
>
Well, an md5sum can be generated for any file. You have to compare it to 
the string  from a known good source to verify the file.

> The Start button 
>is enabled. But when I click start it appears to burn it to DVD, but 
>when it is done all that is on the DVD are the two small files. The 
>ISO that I made on disk with Nautilus is 366 Kb. And I don't 
>remember how I made it, but it must have been wrong.
>  
>
So it sounds like you are burning an iso that contains those two files, 
not an iso that contains the Mandrake installation dvd.

>Part of what I don't understand is why the file I downloaded from 
>Mandriva Club is actually three files, one of which is an ISO that 
>doesn't include the data necessary to burn it to DVD as an image.
>  
>
Without knowing the exact steps you went through at the time, there's no 
way for us to know either. It doesn't really matter anyway. What we need 
to do is determine what you do have, and go forward from here.

Let us know what the results of the md5sum test above is, and we'll try 
to go forward from there.

Russ

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu May 19 10:47:38 2005
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 10:47:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] It's Springtime, so Companies are Migrating
In-Reply-To: <200505182305.j4IN5oRl055176@m5p.com>

On Wed, 18 May 2005, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

> A lot of apps support SunOS-SPARC, most of those are supporting Linux
> when they move to x86. I'm not seeing much news of apps supporting
> SunOS-x86, this could be due to that being less of a revolution, but this
> doesn't give me a good feeling about SunOS-x86.
>
First, a pedantic point about your terminology: SunOS & Solaris are
two different flavors of UNIX. SunOS is a BSD-based flavor that Sun used
to offer, but stopped selling it about 10 years ago; I suspect that they
stopped supporting it at least 5 years ago. Solaris is a SysVr4-based
flavor, & is what Sun currently sells & supports.

In other words, call Sun with a question about SunOS, & they'll likely
tell you to upgrade & hang up on you -- even if you mean Solaris.

Second, about SOLARIS-x86: in short, it's always been the mostly-ignored
step-child of Sun's offerings, & even in the best of times it's never
got much support. (Sun even tried to kill it at least once in the
late 1990s.) The only figure I've ever seen for how many people used it
was back in 1999/2000, & it was pathetic: about 10,000 users. And I
suspect that most of that number were SysAdmins who used it on a home
PC to learn more about the system.

In short, the market for Solaris-x86 is so small that there's no incentive
to advertise for it. But there is third-party support for it out there;
I can speak from personal experience Intel actively supports its NICs
for that OS.

[snip]
>
> If I felt there was compelling reason to think SunOS's future was bright.
> At the moment I'd rather spend time doing things other than engaging in
> unpaid fights with OSes.
>
Learning a new OS always depends on your intent in learning computers.
It can sometimes be useful to experience a new way of solving familiar
problems -- or picking up a niche expertise for the job market. (At the
very least, working with SCO UNIX for a few months gave me more reasons
to recommend avoiding or replacing it than the well-known SCO Group
vs. IBM lawsuit -- which everyone by now has made up their minds about.)

Geoff

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu May 19 11:16:49 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] It's Springtime, so Companies are Migrating

Message-ID: <428CD811.3090703@madboa.com>

On 5/19/05 10:47 AM, Geoff Burling wrote:

> First, a pedantic point about your terminology: SunOS & Solaris are
> two different flavors of UNIX. SunOS is a BSD-based flavor that Sun used
> to offer, but stopped selling it about 10 years ago; I suspect that they
> stopped supporting it at least 5 years ago. Solaris is a SysVr4-based
> flavor, & is what Sun currently sells & supports.

Yes and no. SunOS and Solaris are marketing terms for somewhat, but 
entirely, dissimilar Unix products. The SunOS product line ended with 
version 4.1.3. I still have login rights to SPARC running it:

$ uname -sr
SunOS 4.1.3_U1

The Solaris product line picked up where SunOS left off and became 
"SunOS 5." Hence the odd uname report on a Solaris 9 system:

$ uname -sr
SunOS 5.9

This isn't merely semantics. Many (most? all?) binaries compiled on a 
SunOS 4 box will run unmodified under Solaris.

From ramunro at speakeasy.net  Thu May 19 11:54:00 2005
From: ramunro at speakeasy.net (Robert Munro)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 11:54:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Using K3b to Kreate Koasters
In-Reply-To: <20050519180031.ECA0643C6@ulke.nakedape.cc>
References: <20050519180031.ECA0643C6@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <1116528840.3480.26.camel@griffin>

> On 19 May 2005, at 8:31, John Jordan wrote: 
> On 19 May 2005, at 7:53, Russ Johnson wrote:
> 
> > >Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.iso
> > >Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.md5.asc
> > >Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.sha1.asc
> 
> > You need to "Burn image to disk".

> OK, I tried that. I have the ISO file above in the Burn ISO9660 
> Image window, in the Image to Burn box. But down below it says 
> No Image File Selected and the Start button is grayed out.

> Still confused :(

As someone else said, you don't have a complete (thus valid) ISO file.

I happen to have the Mandriva 10.2 LE ISO files.  Here are their sizes:

733192192 Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-Download-CD1.i586.iso
731850752 Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-Download-CD2.i586.iso
729962496 Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-Download-CD3.i586.iso

Each ISO file is almost 700 MB.  Your 366 KB file is *way* too small.

The following two files merely contain md5 checksums and signatures:

      512 Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-Download-CD.i586.md5.asc
      536 Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-Download-CD.i586.sha1.asc

You can run "md5sum <iso file>" on each ISO file in order to visually
compare the files' official md5 hashes against the files you acquired.

Do "cat <md5.asc file>" to see the file contents -- the md5 checksums.

If you have a few CD-R blanks, you can use cdrecord to burn these ISOs:

Do "cdrecord scanbus" to get the hardware address of your DVD-R drive;
my SCSI CD-R drive is at address "0,3,0", but yours will be different.

Then do "cdrecord -eject dev=<DVD-R address> <ISO file>" to burn each
ISO file.  Substitute your <DVD-R address> and each <ISO file> name.

Hope that helps...

John Jordan wrote:
: On 19 May 2005, at 9:23, chris wrote:
: 
: > Okay, are you sure you are entering the path to the file itself? For
: > example:
: > 
: > /home/username/myfile.iso
: 
: Yes. The files are in /home/jjj/desktop/. After dragging the ISO into 
: the top box, it says:
: 
: file:/home/jjj/Desktop/Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-
: DVD.x86_64.iso
: 
: The iso is 4.3 Gb.  obtained this file by downloading it from 
: MandrivaClub via BitTorrent. Took nearly four days. When it was 
: done BitTorrent said "Done."
: 
: As for Russ' suggestion, I used md5sum command on the ISO file 
: (man, that took a long time on a 4.3 Gb file!). It finally generated 
: the md5sum. I compared this to the file that came with the 
: download, and they are identical.
: 
: Next idea?

The three files you see from the BitTorrent download are due
to having used BitTorrent.  As others have said, they are "checksum"
files and should never be burned onto the DVD, just the iso itself.

Since BitTorrent is very good at checking file integrity, I will
bet (a small amount :-) that your .iso is good.  Nontheless,
hand-checking  it with `md5sum' against the checksum in 

  Mandriva-Linux-2005-Limited-Edition-DVD.x86_64.md5.asc

is always a good idea.

I'm a bit surprised that BitTorrent took 4 days. My
DVD took about 20 hours.  I guess there are not so many "torrents"
on the network for the x86_64 version.

Dean


From john at johntelford.com  Thu May 19 13:47:32 2005
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 13:47:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Software engineering books
In-Reply-To: <428AB22C.1060401@verizon.net>
Message-ID: <r02010500-1041-398DEE60C8A711D9A8A8000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>

The top of my list is:

"The Mythical Man-Month: Anniversary Edition"
Frederick P. Brooks Jr.
Addison-Wesley, Paperback, 2nd edition, Published August 1995
ISBN 0201835959

"Few books on software project management have been as influential and
timeless as The Mythical Man-Month. With a blend of software engineering
facts and thought-provoking opinions, Fred Brooks offers insight for
anyone managing complex projects. These essays draw from his experience
as project manager for the IBM System/360 computer family and then for
OS/360, its massive software system. Now, 20 years after the initial
publication of his book, Brooks has revisited his original ideas and
added new thoughts and advice, both for readers already familiar with
his work and for readers discovering it for the first time.  The added
chapters contain (1) a crisp condensation of all the propositions
asserted in the original book, including Brooks' central argument in The
Mythical Man-Month: that large programming projects suffer management
problems different from small ones due to the division of labor; that
the conceptual integrity of the product is therefore critical; and that
it is difficult but possible to achieve this unity; (2) Brooks' view of
these propositions a generation later; (3) a reprint of his classic 1986
paper "No Silver Bullet"; and (4) today's thoughts on the 1986
assertion, "There will be no silver bullet within ten years."

Check it out:
<http://www.bookpool.com/.x/ti2f77ewy1/ss/1?qs=mythical+man&Go.x=0&Go.y=
0>

...John

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu May 19 15:44:52 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 15:44:52 -0700 (PDT)

>From: Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
> The Solaris product line picked up where SunOS left off and became 
> "SunOS 5." Hence the odd uname report on a Solaris 9 system:
> 
> $ uname -sr
> SunOS 5.9

Not quite. Back with SunOS 4, somewhere around 4.3 or 4.4, Sun marketing
came up with Solaris and chose to rebrand the OS. Something like 4.3.#nnn
or 4.4.#nnn became "Solaris 1.0". The Solaris 1.nnn mapped in a strange
inconsistant way to SunOS 4. With the SysV changeover they called it
"Solaris 2", so there is a pretty sane mapping of Solaris 2.nnn to SunOS
5.nnn versions. Solaris 2.5.1 is the same as SunOS 5.5.1, and Solaris 2.6
is SunOS 5.6. Then they decided to call SunOS 5.7 "Solaris 7", it was
refered to as "Solaris 2.7" in a number of places, but "Solaris 7" was
the official designation; they've continuing this trend up to
"Solaris 10". Java wasn't the first time Sun has played strange games
with version numbers.

I tend to stick to the SunOS designation as that numbering scheme is
consistant. I say SunOS 5.10, and you immediately know what I'm refering
to without having to look it up in a magical book.

I'll second John's vote for Brooks.  But how are you going to separate 
programming from project management?  If you really intend to try, pay 
very close attention to the part about the "surgical team".  Follow 
that by trading all of your cubicles in for a few good doors:

  http://paulgraham.com/gh.html  (Ctrl+f,blender<enter>)

I would also suggest that you read "The Art of Unix Programming" by Eric 
Raymond.  There's a lot of good insight in there about why Unix is the 
way it is, and lots of other good stuff like what unix got right, 
wrong, etc.

  http://www.catb.org/~esr/writings/taoup/

This will also lead you to a lot of references to other essays and books 
(including Brooks.)

I'll add one caveat, which is not to put too much stock in what he says 
about Python (unless you're considering Java (don't do that.))

Perl is the silver bullet. ;-)  (Add salt to this if you don't believe 
me.)

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu May 19 18:23:44 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 18:23:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] It's Springtime, so Companies are Migrating
In-Reply-To: <20050520010301.41C64198C8@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
References: <200505192244.j4JMiqtK069632@m5p.com>
	<20050520010301.41C64198C8@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0505191804140.14542@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 19 May 2005, Dean S. Messing wrote:

> Seriously, I've always found it amusing that the different Linux 
> distributions (and I guess Solaris), although on completely 
> different development paths, have pretty well tracked each other's 
> version numbers for the last 6-7 years, at least for Mandrake, RH, 
> SuSE, and Slackware.  (I have paid no attention to Debian.:-)
>
> This is, I think, more than coincidence.

I can't speak for Slackware, which used to use year numbers for 
versioning (remember Slackware '97?), but for the rest...

Red Hat's versioning dominates. All the way up to Red Hat Linux 9, Red 
Hat had a very consistent, sane policy behind its version numbers. 
Basically, a major version bump meant that a) there was a major new 
kernel version or b) a core component like gcc or glibc went through 
an upgrade that introduced binary incompatibilities.

Mandrake was originally derived from Red Hat, so it's no coincidence 
at all the its versioning has somewhat tracked along...

SuSE entered the American market when Red Hat was at (or nearly at) 
version 4.2, and SuSE arbitrarily set its version number to match Red 
Hat's. I suppose they wanted to suggest a similarity of features and 
software packages -- which wasn't entirely unreasonable, given that 
everyone was building core systems from the same source tarballs -- 
but there's no doubt the marketing folks drove that decision.

I remember a PLUG meeting in 1997 or so attended by Red Hat's Bob 
Young and a marketing guy from the (then-new, now long-gone) SuSE 
America headquarters. The SuSE guy was asked about the extremely 
coicidental version numbering. He tried to explaining by making a 
crack about 4.2 being related to Life, the Universe, and Everything -- 
which caused nothing but groaning and eye-rolling in the peanut 
gallery.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Installing Linux sux.

Edition DVD.x86_64 this afternoon. 

After two and a half hours of installing, plus half an hour scrolling 
through the applications and deciding what I wanted, I got to the 
end and hit the Reboot button. 

It restarted and hung on "- No init found. Try passing init = options 
to kernel." 

I have no idea what the init options are, or whether they would be 
worth trying, let alone the syntax for how to enter them or where. 
No help menus available from this screen. I have a couple Linux 
books, but no index entries address this issue. Google also came 
up empy. Well, empty except for a thousand advertising sites. :( 


Mandriva full DVD from MandrivaClub was kind of my last hope for this 
Compaq R4000. I have tried Suse (did not recognize the video), Knoppix 
(dead keyboard and touchpad), Ubunto (ditto Knoppix), Gentoo (ditto 
Knoppix), and Mandriva. Mandriva was the free three-CD set. It found and 
configured everthing except the video and the wireless. I knew I could 
handle the wireless via Linuxant, if necessary. But the video was a sine 
qua non. 


Well, I have gone all the way through the installation and it won't even

install Windows XP that came with this laptop? 


After six hours trying to install, I am seriously frustrated.

Hi John,

Sorry to hear about your difficulties. Here are my thoughts on this...

John Jordan wrote:

>Dudes and dudettes, 
>
>Installing Linux sux. 
>  
>
It can. Especially when you are installing on something specialized like 
a laptop. Most laptops still to this day have hardware not used in more 
traditional PCs. It's getting better, from both ends, but it can still 
be a headache.

Then you've added a brand new, cutting edge machine into the mix. I 
don't see the laptop you have listed on linux on laptops, which tells me 
that getting help for your specific installation may be slightly more 
difficult than usual.

>It restarted and hung on "- No init found. Try passing init = options 
>to kernel." 
>  
>
For a first install, I'd go strictly with the default packages. 
Customization can happen later. You'll need to know what kind of video 
your laptop has, what pcmcia chipset, and maybe several other things. 
Most likely each of these will require a reinstall to "get it right". 
Some may only require rebuilding the kernel.

When I installed linux on my HP laptop the first time, it hung on boot 
as well. I at least got it to boot. I had to disable PCMCIA before it 
would boot completely.

Then, I had to recompile the kernel to get ACPI to work. The ACPI 
chipset in mine wouldn't work at all with APM even turned on in the 
kernel. It had to be completely removed.

>I have no idea what the init options are, or whether they would be 
>worth trying, let alone the syntax for how to enter them or where. 
>No help menus available from this screen. I have a couple Linux 
>books, but no index entries address this issue. Google also came 
>up empy. Well, empty except for a thousand advertising sites. :( 
>  
>
I'd back up a bit and start with an easy installation. Once things start 
to work and you start to understand a little more about how linux 
interacts with your laptop hardware, you can work on when init options, 
if any, it needs.

>Mandriva full DVD from MandrivaClub was kind of my last hope for this 
>Compaq R4000.
>
I seriously doubt that any distribution works completely, out of the 
box, on this particular laptop. It's quite new, if I'm reading the 
information HP has on it.

-- 
Russ Johnson

http://www.dimstar.net

John Jordan wrote:
> Installing Linux sux. 

You've obviously never installed Windows.

> Mandriva full DVD from MandrivaClub was kind of my last hope for this 
> Compaq R4000. I have tried Suse (did not recognize the video), Knoppix 
> (dead keyboard and touchpad), Ubunto (ditto Knoppix), Gentoo (ditto 
> Knoppix), and Mandriva. Mandriva was the free three-CD set. It found and 
> configured everthing except the video and the wireless. I knew I could 
> handle the wireless via Linuxant, if necessary. But the video was a sine 
> qua non. 

Every one of those issues is something that's likely easily fixed.  If
it works one place, it can work everywhere.

Just because the automagic configurator thingimijig didn't configure
something for you doesn't mean it's a lost cause.  I'll bet we can get
your video working in Mandriva or SuSE, your keyboard and touchpad
working in Ubantu, Knoppix, or Gentoo.  I'd personally toss Slackware in
to the mix as well, if for no other reason than it seems to often have
different default kernel options than the other big boys out there.

Now, let's just say you want to stick with Mandriva for the moment, at
least to get your feet wet in Linux.  What doesn't work about the video?
 Are you trying to start video by default at bootup or log in to the
console and start X manually?

What kind of info is appearing either on the console or
/var/log/Xorg.0.log after X fails to start?  Take some of the key terms
down at the bottom of it and google them.  What kind of video chip do
you have in your laptop?  You may find trying a VESA default style
driver might work better, at least to get started, than something
specific for your chipset.

Rob

Dean S. Messing wrote:

> Is this an example of "Version Inflation"?

Partly. As Geoff pointed out, the switch from SunOS to Solaris was 
partly a shift in the technology, it wasn't all marketing. But I'm sure 
that Sun was very concerned that they were still on numbers like 2.5 and 
2.6 while the Linux distributions were coming out with new major version 
numbers very quickly in comparison. They clearly didn't want to end up 
in a situation where someone was choosing between something like SunOS 
3.1 and RedHat 6.0.

The goofy part is that the other style of numbers do still show up on 
the system. When you boot up Solaris 10 is says "SunOS Release 5.10." 
That's not a very hard mapping to remember, though.

> Seriously, I've always found it amusing that the different Linux
> distributions (and I guess Solaris), although on completely different
> development paths, have pretty well tracked each other's version
> numbers for the last 6-7 years, at least for Mandrake, RH, SuSE, and
> Slackware.  (I have paid no attention to Debian.:-)
> 
> This is, I think, more than coincidence.

Well, Mandrake and SuSE were pretty RedHat-based at first, weren't they? 
I think they've evolved in pretty different directions, but it's not 
suprising to me that their versioning has stayed pretty consistent with 
RedHat's. I'm sure marketing plays a big part of it too.


Rich

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri May 20 09:53:06 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 09:53:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] filenames with spaces, shell programming ...
In-Reply-To: <86mzqpdf3w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86mzqpdf3w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <428E15F2.5060806@madboa.com>

On 5/20/05 9:41 AM, Russell Senior wrote:
> I have got a file containing file names with spaces and exclamation 
> marks, etc.  I want to, e.g., cmp -v two versions of these files, 
> something like:
> 
> $ cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo
> 
> When I stupidly do something like:
> 
> $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v $DIR1/$foo
> $DIR2/$foo ; done
> 
> the filenames get split at spaces in the filenames.  How do I keep 
> them from being split?

I typically combine find -print0 with xargs -0, though it might be tough 
to duplicate your loop exactly. In a directory containing files or 
directories with spaces in their names, compare these three commands:

1. find * -prune | xargs stat
2. for f in *; do stat $f; done
3. find * -prune -print0 | xargs -0 stat

The first two do roughly the same thing: tokenize filenames on 
whitespace so that you end up with bad results or errors.

The last one does the right thing: find null-terminates the results and 
xargs splits on the null terminator, not whitespace.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

On 5/20/05 9:58 AM, Wil Cooley wrote:

>> When I stupidly do something like:
>> 
>> $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v $DIR1/$foo
>> $DIR2/$foo ; done
>> 
>> the filenames get split at spaces in the filenames.  How do I keep 
>> them from being split?
> 
> Double-quotes around shell variables?
> 
> cmp -v "$DIR1/$foo" "$DIR2/$foo"
> 
> I'm not sure about the exclamation points though; lemme know if the 
> quotes handle those too.

The problem actually occurs earlier, in the for loop. The shell will 
assign $foo based on whitespace splits in the string returned by $(cat 
fnames). The quoting you suggest may help if $foo contains shell 
metacharacters, but it won't solve the whitespace issue.

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Fri May 20 10:06:02 2005
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 10:06:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] filenames with spaces, shell programming ...
In-Reply-To: <86mzqpdf3w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86mzqpdf3w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <428E18FA.6090401@easystreet.com>

Russell Senior wrote:

>I have got a file containing file names with spaces and exclamation
>marks, etc.  I want to, e.g., cmp -v two versions of these files,
>something like:
>
>  $ cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo
>
>When I stupidly do something like:
>
>  $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo ; done
>
>the filenames get split at spaces in the filenames.  How do I keep
>them from being split?
>
Try

   $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v "$DIR1/$foo" "$DIR2/$foo" ; done

The variables will expand inside the double-quotes, but the shell
will still pass them as singe strings to cmp(1).  Now, as for the
exclamation points .... those might be an uglier problem.

On Friday 20 May 2005 11:41, Russell Senior wrote:
> I have got a file containing file names with spaces and exclamation
> marks, etc.  I want to, e.g., cmp -v two versions of these files,
> something like:
>
>   $ cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo
>
> When I stupidly do something like:
>
>   $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo
> ; done
>
> the filenames get split at spaces in the filenames.  How do I keep
> them from being split?
>
> When this issue has come up in the past, Randal usually pipes up with
> a solution that subtley implies that "you don't understand how this
> works".  I guess I need to improve my understanding at this stage.
>
> Any lucid explanation welcome.

I'm sure someone will come up with a more elegant solution but in this example 
I replace the spaces with a "#" character and then as each filename is 
processed, the "#" is translated back to a space character...Pretty lame I 
know...

#!/bin/sh
#
names=`sed -e 's/ /#/g' fnames`
for foo in $names; do
  fname=`echo "$foo" | tr "#" " "`
  echo "$fname";
done

Tony

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

Subject: [PLUG] Re: suid
In-Reply-To: <20050520171838.23413.qmail@web31601.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

On Fri, 2005-05-20 at 10:18 -0700, Nick Wehr wrote:
> in Gentoo I want a perl (or sh) script to run as a specific user (not root)...
> I chmod ug+s it while I'm the desired user, however, it still doesn't work as I
> expect.  /etc/ftab doesn't prevent suid... what gives?

SUID on scripts has never been supported on Linux and most, if not all,
modern UNIX systems do not support it because it's a security risk.  If
Perl, look into suidperl, which is built to work around this.
Otherwise, use sudo.

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:

Paul> I typically combine find -print0 with xargs -0, though it might
Paul> be tough to duplicate your loop exactly. In a directory
Paul> containing files or directories with spaces in their names,
Paul> compare these three commands:

Paul> 1. find * -prune | xargs stat 2. for f in *; do stat $f; done
Paul> 3. find * -prune -print0 | xargs -0 stat

Paul> The first two do roughly the same thing: tokenize filenames on
Paul> whitespace so that you end up with bad results or errors.

Paul> The last one does the right thing: find null-terminates the
Paul> results and xargs splits on the null terminator, not whitespace.

>>>>> "Wil" == Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> writes:

Wil> On Fri, 2005-05-20 at 09:41 -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
>> I have got a file containing file names with spaces and exclamation
>> marks, etc.  I want to, e.g., cmp -v two versions of these files,
>> something like:
>> 
>> $ cmp -v $DIR1/$foo $DIR2/$foo
>> 
>> When I stupidly do something like:
>> 
>> $ for foo in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $foo ; cmp -v $DIR1/$foo
>> $DIR2/$foo ; done
>> 
>> the filenames get split at spaces in the filenames.  How do I keep
>> them from being split?

Wil> Double-quotes around shell variables?

Wil> cmp -v "$DIR1/$foo" "$DIR2/$foo"

Wil> I'm not sure about the exclamation points though; lemme know if
Wil> the quotes handle those too.

That's too late, I think.  The for loop already has $foo as
space-split tokens.  Wrapping them in quotes will just quote the
mis-split tokens.  E.g.:

  $ touch "a b c" "d e f"
  $ ls -1 * > fnames
  $ for i in $(cat fnames) ; do echo $i ; done
  a
  b 
  c 
  d 
  e
  f

On 5/20/05 11:19 AM, Russell Senior wrote:

> Problem is, I am more or less stuck with the file of filenames as a
> starting point.  I need to re-tokenize them, I guess, but how?

I think it's actually easier at that point, assuming you're using bash 
and can take advantage of its funky, somewhat mystical ability to read 
whole lines when using shell redirection to pipe a file into a while loop:

while read f
do
   echo "$f"
   cmp -v "/foo/$f" "/bar/$f"
done < fnames

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Mandriva Installation Woes
In-Reply-To: <20050520172635.A211D44B4@ulke.nakedape.cc>

On Fri, 2005-05-20 at 08:35 -0700, John Jordan wrote:

> OK, the reinstall resulted in the same exact problem. Still hangs on
> "Kernel panic - not syncing: No init found. Try passing init= option 
> to kernel"

I had a similar symptom the first time I tried to install this release
(although I have a 32-bit system, not 64-bit).  I sent the boot loader
to the root partition and it somehow overwrote something important and
caused a kernal panic.  When I put LILO on the MBR, it booted up okay.

> At this point I wonder if it would do any good to keep reinstalling.

You should be able to get it installed successfully.  Try another way.
I'd suggest using separate partitions, i.e., extended logical partitions
something like this:

hda  5  /boot       32 MB
     6  /          256 MB
     7  /home     1024 MB
     8  /var       512 MB
     9  swap      1024 MB
    10  /usr      3072 MB
    11  /usr/local 512 MB
    12  /data   ~53600 MB   

Using extended logical partitions leaves some space for the boot loader
to overrun.  At least, that's what I thought when doing this worked out.
You can toggle to Expert Mode in the HardDrake partitioning utility and
set the partition type to Extended.  Just be sure to do it on all disks.

> In reading what is on the screen after it hangs, I am encouraged to 
> see that it recognized a lot of stuff....

That's encouraging.  If you can just get it to boot, it might work fine.

> So I am still hoping!

Good.  Try varying how you do the install, especially the partitioning,
and make sure to put LILO on the MBR rather than on the root partition.

Best of luck...

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri May 20 13:53:44 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 13:53:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] It's Springtime, so Companies are Migrating
In-Reply-To: <20050520153053.46D954443@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200505202053.j4KKritV083479@m5p.com>

>From: Rich Burroughs <rich at paranoid.org>
> Dean S. Messing wrote:
> 
> > Is this an example of "Version Inflation"?
> 
> Partly. As Geoff pointed out, the switch from SunOS to Solaris was 
> partly a shift in the technology, it wasn't all marketing. But I'm sure 

Initially it was actually version deflation. But the "Solaris" moniker is
*pure* marketing. The shift in technology was from SunOS 4 to SunOS 5,
which correspond with Solaris 1 and Solaris 2. So it was officially
Solaris well before the shift. Initially this had the effect of deflating
the version numbers, but the major version number still represented major
change. Now the Solaris versions are pure marketing fluff.

> The goofy part is that the other style of numbers do still show up on 
> the system. When you boot up Solaris 10 is says "SunOS Release 5.10." 
> That's not a very hard mapping to remember, though.

Not entirely goofy. The SunOS version numbers are assigned by Sun
Engineering, who are interested in meaningful version numbers; rather
than by Sun Marketing who just want larger version numbers. `uname -r`
will give you the SunOS version, which is a heck of a lot more useful for
scripting than the Solaris numbers.

installing Linux, but most likely have never done a bare installation of

>From: "John Jordan" <johnxj at comcast.net>
> When it finished I rebooted and it ran about two pages of code and 
> hung. Looking at the screen again there is more that might be 
> helpful in diagnosing what went wrong - 
> 
> mounting root filesystem with flags noatime mount: error 6 
> mounting ext3 flags noatime well, retrying read-only without any 
> flags mount: error 6 mounting ext3 pivotroot: pivot_root (sysroot, 
> /sysroot / initrd) failed: 2 Initrd finished Freeing unused Kernel 
> memory: 220 K freed Kernel panic - not syncing: No init found. Try 
> passing     init= option to Kernel 

You've dropped a bunch of newlines which would of been nice to keep, but
oh well. The suggestion of passing "init=" to the kernel would be useless
in this case, since it appears to be failing to mount the root
filesystem; it doesn't say that since it has loaded an initrd and so
tries to boot off that (which is unfortunately useless).

At a guess either the initrd has a bad view of the universe and is trying
to mount the wrong device as the root filesystem, or perhaps the initrd
is missing or failing to load a driver needed to access the root device.
Alas that is all I can say, as I generally avoid using initrd nor do I
have experience with Mandrake.

Anyone played with Mandrake's initrd stuff?

From johnxj at comcast.net  Fri May 20 15:15:55 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Mandriva Installation Woes

On 20 May 2005, at 14:08, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

> Yes, but the most recent analysis I've seen stated that it was a *lot*
> better than Windows installation. The reason you notice is because
> you're installing Linux, but most likely have never done a bare
> installation of Windows (a recovery CD/DVD doesn't count).

Actually, I have. Many, many times. I have never bought a 
computer with Windows preinstalled. In fact, the last time I bought 
a computer that I did not build myself was so long ago it was a 
386/25, state of the art for its day.

In the early days (like 3.0 and even 3.1) there were lots of driver 
problems. Unstable is an understatement. To get away from the 
shell crashing all the time I built my first NT computer in October, 
1993, two months after NT 3.1 was released. And there were driver 
problems with that too, for several years. 

Even if there were drivers for NT they frequently didn't work well. 
The problem was that NT required different drivers than regular 
Windows and manufacturers did not want to spend the money on 
producing a driver for an OS until after it had a decent market 
share. (Gosh, that sounds kind of familiar, doesn't it?) As a result, 
for the first release of NT the drivers were almosst all written by 
Microsoft. And Microsoft didn't care if they had all the functionality 
the device was capable of. All they wanted was to be able to say 
"why of course NT comes with a driver for your Mark IV BugBomb 
card."

Today those issues are all pretty much behind us for Windows. But 
now I'm trying to go to Linux, and having to go through it all over 
again. But I'm cool with it. With this laptop my trump card is that I 
still have ten days left on my "no hassle" return privilege with HP. 
I'm just frustrated. I *really, really like* this computer. I so want to 
get Linux working on it properly.

As for Mandriva, I did have Mandriva installed on it and it worked 
fine (except the video was wrong and the wireless and firewire didn't 
work). But the version that I had installed was the 586 version, and 
now I'm trying to install .x86_64.

Also, I think the firewire didn't work because Mandriva thought it 
was eth0. The LAN was eth1. And I had to do a lot of fiddling with 
the LAN to get it up so I could get on the internet. Unfortunately, 
every time the window came up eth0 was in the drop down menu 
by default. So most of the time when I made a change I ended up 
trying to do it to the firewire port. Only after seeing the hourglass 
followed by an error message did I realize that, once again, I had 
forgotten to select eth1 before applying the change. So I'm pretty 
sure the firewire didn't work becauses I goobered it up.

(Note to Gnome coders: Make that drop down box "sticky" so once 
the user selects a device it will keep coming up with that device by 
default. Or make the box blink and make loud squealing noises 
until the user selects a device. Or something. It's a user interface 
problem the way it is now.)

As for the wireless, I am sure that can be made to work. Push 
come to shove, I can go to Linuxant and pay a few bux for their fix. 
I never got to the point of trying the faxmodem but, again, Linuxant 
will probably save me if the distro doesn't get it going automatically.

It's the video that may be the deal killer here. But I am still hoping 
that the full 64-bit version of Mandriva 2005 LE will do it. 

I just went out running some errands and had some time to 
cogitate on this some more. I think for my next exercise I am going 
to try a reinstall, but select Ext2 instead of Ext3. Or maybe Reiser. 
And, as Robert suggested, maybe I'll change the partition sizes.

NOT GIVING UP YET!

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun May 15 17:12:59 2005
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 17:12:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless gateway firewall wrong.
Message-ID: <20050516001259.1BEBA1F554@goose.robinson-west.com>

The following is my firewall on my wireless router that doesn't
properly forward port 80,443 traffic.  I tried to send it as an
rc.local attachment before, but the attachment got stripped.


#!/bin/sh
#
# /etc/rc.d/rc.local:  Local system initialization script.
#
# Put any local setup commands in here:

/etc/rc.d/rc.wireless wlan0
/sbin/ifconfig wlan0 10.0.0.1
/sbin/iwconfig wlan0 mode ad-hoc

iptables -P INPUT ACCEPT
iptables -P OUTPUT ACCEPT
###############################################################



  OUT_INT_1="wlan0"
   IN_INT_1="eth0"
  PRIVPORTS="0:1023"
UNPRIVPORTS="1024:65535"

   OUT_ADDR_1="10.0.0.1"
  REMOTE_ADDR="10.0.0.2"
REMOTE_ADDR_2="10.0.0.3"

 SSH_LOCAL_PORTS="1022:65535"
SSH_REMOTE_PORTS="513:65535"

WIFI2="10.0.0.0/8"



iptables -F
iptables -F -t nat
iptables -F -t mangle
iptables -X
iptables -P FORWARD DROP 



###############################################################
#echo "ICMP packets section."

iptables -N icmpi
iptables -N icmpo



iptables -A icmpi --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type echo-reply \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpi --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type destination-unreachable -d $OUT_ADDR_1 \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpi --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type source-quench -d $OUT_ADDR_1 \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpi --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type time-exceeded -d $OUT_ADDR_1 \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpi --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type parameter-problem -d $OUT_ADDR_1 \
         -j ACCEPT



iptables -A icmpo --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --icmp-type fragmentation-needed \
         -j ACCEPT


iptables -A icmpo --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --icmp-type source-quench \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpo --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --icmp-type parameter-problem \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A icmpo --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p icmp \
         --icmp-type echo-request \
         -j ACCEPT



iptables -A INPUT -j icmpi
iptables -A OUTPUT -j icmpo
###############################################################



###############################################################
#echo "Stateful rules."

#
# Kill malformed XMAS packets.
#

iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL ALL -j DROP

iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL ALL -j DROP

#
# Kill malformed NULL packets.
#

iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL NONE -j DROP

iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp --tcp-flags ALL NONE -j DROP

###############################################################



###############################################################
# Allow local traffic.

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface lo -j ACCEPT
iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface lo -j ACCEPT
iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $IN_INT_1 -j ACCEPT
iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $IN_INT_1 -j ACCEPT

# End of allow local traffic.
###############################################################



###############################################################
# Allow remote ssh.

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp \
         --source-port $SSH_REMOTE_PORTS \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port 22 -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp ! --syn \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port 22 \
         --destination-port $SSH_REMOTE_PORTS -j ACCEPT

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp ! --syn \
         --source-port 22 -d $OUT_ADDR_1 \
         --destination-port $SSH_LOCAL_PORTS \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port $SSH_LOCAL_PORTS \
         --destination-port 22 -j ACCEPT

# End of Allow remote ssh.
###############################################################



###############################################################
# Allow web browsing.

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp ! --syn \
         --source-port 443 \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         --destination-port 443 -j ACCEPT

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp ! --syn \
         --source-port 80 \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         --destination-port 80 -j ACCEPT

# End of allow web browsing.
###############################################################



###############################################################
# Allow DNS Server.

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         --source-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port 53 -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port 53 \
         --destination-port $UNPRIVPORTS -j ACCEPT

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         --source-port 53 \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port 53 -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port 53 \
         --destination-port 53 -j ACCEPT

# End of Allow DNS Server.
###############################################################



###############################################################
# Allow DNS Client.

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         --source-port 53 \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p udp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         --destination-port 53 -j ACCEPT

iptables -A INPUT --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp ! --syn \
         --source-port 53 \
         -d $OUT_ADDR_1 --destination-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT --out-interface $OUT_INT_1 -p tcp \
         -s $OUT_ADDR_1 --source-port $UNPRIVPORTS \
         --destination-port 53 -j ACCEPT

# End of Allow DNS Client.
###############################################################



###############################################################
# Masquerade

#echo "Allow associated packets from outbound connections"
#echo "back in."

iptables -A FORWARD -i $IN_INT_1 -o $OUT_INT_1 -m state \
         --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -d $REMOTE_ADDR \
         -j ACCEPT

iptables -A FORWARD -i $IN_INT_1 -o $OUT_INT_1 -m state \
         --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -d $REMOTE_ADDR_2 \
         -j ACCEPT



iptables -A FORWARD -m state --state NEW,ESTABLISHED \
         --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 \
         --out-interface $IN_INT_1 \
         -s $REMOTE_ADDR -j ACCEPT

iptables -A FORWARD -m state --state NEW,ESTABLISHED \
         --in-interface $OUT_INT_1 \
         --out-interface $IN_INT_1 \
         -s $REMOTE_ADDR_2 -j ACCEPT



iptables -A POSTROUTING -t nat -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

###############################################################



#ip route flush table 2 2>/dev/null
#
#ip rule add fwmark 3 table 2
#
#ip route add default via 192.168.4.2 dev eth0 table 2
#
#iptables -A PREROUTING -t mangle -s 10.0.0.2 -j MARK --set-mark 3 \
#         -p tcp --dport 80
#
#iptables -A PREROUTING -t mangle -s 10.0.0.3 -j MARK --set-mark 3 \
#         -p tcp --dport 80
#
#iptables -A PREROUTING -t mangle -s 10.0.0.2 -j MARK --set-mark 3 \
#         -p tcp --dport 443
#
#iptables -A PREROUTING -t mangle -s 10.0.0.3 -j MARK --set-mark 3 \
#         -p tcp --dport 443

iptables -P INPUT DROP
iptables -P OUTPUT DROP

Richard Steffens,

Do you simply use imap or do you use a local smtp server on your
box to send email?

Is a packet filter blocking outbound connections to port 143 on
comcast's server or the packets coming back?

Is host resolution properly configured on your machine?

Maybe comcast has used a strange feature of the Winders client
where something you are not aware of has to happen for port
143 or 25 on their server to open.  

To see what servers your running if your doing your own smtp server,
the netstat command is useful.  I use netstat -nlptu frequently.  If 
you can do tcpdump on the winders box to see what the traffic looks 
like from your imap client that can send email, maybe you'll see 
what's special.

I would complain to Comcast if asking for more information from 
them doesn't help.  Over time, it seems that Comcast has 
consistently been problematic for people.  One way to improve 
things is to vote with your money for broadband providers that 
are Linux friendly.  Boycott Comcast if it's too hard to use it.
If I had the money I could have Comcast as well as DSL, but
now especially I know I don't want it.  Satellite service
might even be better ( except for Starband ).

A high level and very well known development company is looking for a few candidates to help evaluate a new C++ compiler. This company is in the process of evaluating a new version and wants "real world" people to provide feedback and make design recommendations. The product evaluation is informal. It will involve experienced software developers who currently hold, or have held, a position where software development is/was a significant portion of their responsibility. In addition, candidates also need

 - programmed in C++ for at least a year,

 - developed C++ code within the last month,
 - worked with Linux or Unix,
 - not purchased a C++ compiler in the last year,
 - perform a number of C++ tasks [hence the questions about experience.] 

Evaluation sessions are held in Hillsboro and will run approximately two hours. Each participant will receive $100 honorarium as compensation for their time. Session times available are:

From larry.brigman at gmail.com  Fri May 20 22:20:44 2005
From: larry.brigman at gmail.com (Larry Brigman)
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 22:20:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for a keylogger infection...
In-Reply-To: <1116358762.428a486aece5d@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1116358762.428a486aece5d@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <ca51655305052022206351ee16@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/17/05, plug_0 at robinson-west.com <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
...
> Is there a program I should burn to a cd and install to my
> friend's computer that will find any keylogger that might
> be there?  Does anyone know a specific file name to search
> for or something that will be in the registry that will
> indicate a keylogger is installed?

I would first start with a good virus scanner with up to date defs like
clamwin.  Then scan the system with three different ad-ware/spyware 
scanner programs. my recommends Microsoft antispyware,
spysweeper and TDS-3.

The problem with all of this is that there could still be custom spam bots
and keyloggers that are under the radar of the people that write all of these
programs.

Best and safest. Get the data off the box. wipe the disk re-install and then
behind a good firewall (or have Linux download and burn a CD) download all
the XP patches.  Microsoft's site is the first and only site you hit
until everything
is patched.

Did you heard the news report about attaching a fresh XP install with all the
security patches and then let some teenagers serf the web for an hour.

backups, NTFS partition resizing and moving from
one disk to another is BootItNG.  I had one machine
that nothing we tried worked, it would either die while
trying to image the drive or the imaged drive would
not boot.  BootItNG worked the first time.  Haven't looked
around since.


From aaron at bavariati.org  Fri May 20 22:51:53 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 22:51:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Spam confession
Message-ID: <20050521055153.GP30750@bavariati.org>

Bless me Tux for I have sinned.

I left my SMTP relay open for nearly a day.  And a spammer used it!

The relay is now closed, and has passed the MAPS scan.  I understand
what I have done and how it came to happen, and I shall nevermore use
SSH to forward port 25 without the proper precautions.
          _______________________________________

Postfix is very good about not being an open relay, and I'd carefully
set things up with SASLauthd so that users had to authenticate to the
server before they could relay mail through it.  The only way someone
can relay mail through the box without authentication is if they're on
the box's internal (127.0.0.1) network.  This allows daemons to send
alert mails and suchlike.

I was moving the mail server from one IP address (and site) to
another.  I wanted to change the address in DNS beforehand so there'd
be time for the change to propagate without a service interruption.

I set up a system at the new address, then had it forward incoming
port 25 traffic to the old address via an SSH portforward.  All worked
nicely.  But I forgot something: SSH forwards to the internal
(127.0.0.1) network.  Yes, the one that Postfix accepts mail from
without authentication.  So by forwarding port 25 to the internal
network on the mail server, the box at the new address looked like a
perfectly ordinary open relay!

And one of the many, many spammers who troll for open relays found it.

So beware of the unintended consequences of portforwards.

Our Kernel, which Art in Ring 0...
  Aaron

In-Reply-To: <86r7g19kbl.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> Following up on the shell question I had earlier today, I
Russell> have a set of 184 files (from Samba server rsync snapshots).
Russell> They are .doc, .xls, .ppt, and .gz files with identical
Russell> filesize and timestamps.  [...]

Russell> Er, actually, no .doc files: .xls (162) and .ppt (12)
Russell> primarily (also one each .wmf, .bmp and .jnb, a scientific
Russell> graphing program, the rest are .gz).

I also looked at the .bmp file and the backup looked wrong there as
well.  So I found the affected inodes:

  while read f ; do ls -i "$f" ; done < ~/bogus-fnames | sort > ~/bogus-inodes

and the file names that point at those inodes:

  find . -printf "%i %P\n" | sort > ~/inode-map

and built a shell script to repoint the filenames at the "good" inodes
of a fresh "rsync -c" backup:

  join ~/bogus-inodes ~/inode-map | awk 'BEGIN { print "#!/bin/bash" } { print "ln -vf \"" $2 "\" \"" $3 "\"" }' > patchup-snapshots.sh

... or words to that effect.  I also kept a copy of the "corrupt"
versions in case we later discover in some instances they are actually
good.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat May 21 21:41:17 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 May 2005 21:41:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] The Clinic is ON

>>>>> "John" == John Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> writes:

John> A thousand thanks to all of you. The clinic was great! OK,
John> problem not resolved, but I know more about what is causing
John> it. And I learned a LOT about Linux! Totally cool afternoon!

Russ> When you finally get it working, please consider doing a writeup
Russ> and submitting it to the linux-on-laptops website.

John> I definitely will. [...]

For the edification of onlookers, the main problem we ran into was
booting into the Mandriva 10.2 64bit install.  What appeared to be
happening is that the ext3 root filesystem failed to mount during the
initrd phase, and so the subsequent pivot_root and execution of init
(located, of course, on the root filesystem) failed.  The ext3.ko
module seemed to load.

I have no experience with Mandr-ake/-iva, or 64bit platforms, or
really much with initrd's.  From mailing list traffic, people seem to
be running this distribution elsewhere, so not sure what our specific
problem was.  I think our initrd.img was probably bad for some reason,
and my advice was to post to the Mandriva mailing lists to inquire
about the problem.  Or maybe udev wasn't creating the /dev/hdaN
devices quickly enough for them to appear in time to mount.

One possible thing to try would be to try installing to an ext2
filesystem instead of ext3.  It might not solve your problem, but it
might help illuminate what the real problem is.  If we had a
cross-building environment for a 64-bit target, we might be able to
just compile up a kernel version that didn't need an initrd and punt
around that problem.

Any other ideas, people?

From rich at paranoid.org  Sun May 22 07:58:49 2005

	<86wtpr98k2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <42909E29.70904@paranoid.org>

Russell Senior wrote:

> I have no experience with Mandr-ake/-iva, or 64bit platforms, or
> really much with initrd's.  From mailing list traffic, people seem to
> be running this distribution elsewhere, so not sure what our specific
> problem was.  I think our initrd.img was probably bad for some reason,
> and my advice was to post to the Mandriva mailing lists to inquire
> about the problem.  Or maybe udev wasn't creating the /dev/hdaN
> devices quickly enough for them to appear in time to mount.
> 
> One possible thing to try would be to try installing to an ext2
> filesystem instead of ext3.  It might not solve your problem, but it
> might help illuminate what the real problem is.  If we had a
> cross-building environment for a 64-bit target, we might be able to
> just compile up a kernel version that didn't need an initrd and punt
> around that problem.
> 
> Any other ideas, people?

You could try ext2, I would be surprised if it made a difference but who 
knows.

The real question for me is whether there is support for all of the 
hardware needed to boot in the initrd, especially things like the disk 
controller and filesystems. There's not too much to know about initrd, 
you just need to make sure that all of the necessary hardware support is 
either in the kernel itself or available as a module in the initrd.

If Mandriva has a hardware compatability list, that would be a good 
place to start. Posting to their list is a good idea too. People come 
here with a lot of problems that I would usually take to the 
distro-specific list. Sometimes what seems like an odd error to us here 
is a known issue to the people on the distro's support list :)


Rich

I've had an HPT302 (not a raid controller) in my workstation for a 
couple of years now.  It slows down the boot process (while the card 
posts the drives it found) but I've never seen an ATA controller that 
didn't do that.

I've also got one of their SATA controllers (still not raid) in my 
fileserver.  No problems with either of them since day 1 (bye bye 
Promise) except that the install instructions were a little lacking 
(but that was a boot-drive changeover from the onboard controller with 
an installed RH7.3 that didn't have scsi support in the initrd.)

From nix at petelancashire.com  Sun May 22 09:40:18 2005
From: nix at petelancashire.com (Pete Lancashire)
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 09:40:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RAID controller for a linux box
In-Reply-To: <200505220922.39758.ewilhelm@sbcglobal.net>
References: <BAY20-F42CEC7F86898C6677CE306B80B0@phx.gbl>
	<200505220922.39758.ewilhelm@sbcglobal.net>
Message-ID: <1116780018.9188.5.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

What are you trying to accomplish in RAID ?

If it is performance with RAID5 be careful.

If your write sizes are large, Cache size
is going to be very important.

Just as important is the speed at which the
parity can be processed, especially if
the cache size is small, and things slow
down waiting for parity blocks to be created.

Seen too many RAID systems where their
performance sucks.

-pete

frustration over various 3rd-party things (like Flash and Java for 
instance) caused me to switch back to the 32-bit version.  Unless you 
have more than 4GB of memory or are doing some truely intense things 
that take advantage of the larger instruction size, I don't think you'll 
even notice the difference between the two, and 32-bit is still better 
supported.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun May 22 13:57:33 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 13:57:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] amd 64 distros
In-Reply-To: <42908006.8848.EAB8EDA@localhost>
References: <42908006.8848.EAB8EDA@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0505221351030.12572@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 22 May 2005, John Jordan wrote:

> Add Graphics Card, so I clicked on it. This brought up a list of
> manufacturers, and when I clicked on ATI I got a list of video cards. But
> the Radeon Xpress 200 was still not listed. I even restarted the computer,
> but the Radeon Xpress 200 is still not listed.

> I looked at the knowledgebase on suse.com, but couldn't find anything that
> addressed how to install a new graphics card driver.

John,

   From within a virtual terminal, what do you see when you run 'lsmod' (list
modules) as root? The commands to load a module into the kernel are insmod
(the simpler of the two) and modprobe.

   You can try loading the appropriate driver (for XFree86 or X.org) manually
and see what your display does. When you confirm that it works, you can add
the driver to the same location as other loaded drivers and tell SuSE/Mandr*
to load them by putting the driver path and name where all loaded modules
are specified. (I've no idea where that is on your distributions, but in
Slackware it's /etc/rc.d/rc.modules.)

HTH,

Rich

I'm sure there are folks on this list who'll be willing to flame me for
saying this, but as far as I'm concerned, I consider Java run-times or
compilers other than Sun's a dead waste of my time, and my
recommendation is that you do likewise. Yes, I know, the Sun offerings
are not free as in freedom, yes, I know about the "Java trap".
(http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/java-trap.html). There is an awful lot of
good software out there written in Java; if it "happens" to work on
other environments, fine and dandy.

So ... take it to PLUG-TALK if you want to flame me. My experiences with
jikes and blackdown were negative; I gave up on them.

> I'm sure there are folks on this list who'll be willing to flame me
> for saying this, but as far as I'm concerned, I consider Java
> run-times or compilers other than Sun's a dead waste of my time, and

Well, I might agree with you on the runtime issue:  it's wise to use
Sun's unless you've specific reasons not to.  But as for the compiler, I
find jikes superior to javac for its speed.  Been using it for several
years without problems.  Jikes has been very compliant to spec'; but if
I were worried about that, I would still use it on my development box,
and then I would use javac when testing and building for production. 
The main reason is, I save a little time that way every time I compile a
source file (and jikes will output errors in "Emacs format", which
allows my IDE to jump to the line and column of each error).  In other
words, jikes makes me more productive while coding.

So, Mr. Lofstrom, can you detail the problem you're having with jikes? 
Are you writing code specific to Java 1.5, perchance?

--Jason

From alan at clueserver.org  Sun May 22 22:33:04 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 22:33:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] AWStats from fedora.us -- security bug
Message-ID: <1116826384.3868.4.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

If you have awstats installed on any machine connected to the net, you
want to make sure you have the most up to date version.  If you have
installed the version from fedora.us, you need to upgrade to the real
current version ASAP.

Awstats has a remote program execution vulnerability.  The current
stable version is 6.4. You want to make sure you have at least that
version.

The bug is actively being exploited on the net.  I know. I just got hit
with it.

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

| Just out of curiosity, why are you so intent on using a 64-bit distro? I
| had FC3 64-bit version installed my laptop for about a week, but
| frustration over various 3rd-party things (like Flash and Java for
| instance) caused me to switch back to the 32-bit version.  Unless you
| have more than 4GB of memory or are doing some truely intense things
| that take advantage of the larger instruction size, I don't think you'll
| even notice the difference between the two, and 32-bit is still better
| supported.

With some minor tweaks to your yum repos, you can install 64-bit and
32-bit versions of most libraries and some applications.  It really
sounds like your main problem is getting flash and java plugins to work
(which I count as a blessing, even when my roommate complains).  The
"solution" to this is to uninstall the x86_64 version of mozilla or
firefox and install the i386 one. Yum understands architectures through
the use of ".":

# yum install firefox.i386

will install the i386 (32-bit) version of firefox.  I'm pretty sure
you'll have to remove the x86_64 version first or it will conflict, but
not 100% certain.

One quote from the above:

-----
If, on Windows startup, there are not the required seven Yes votes,
the system will, in the original version of Windows XP, only boot to
Safe Mode. You will be required to reactivate by a phone call to
Microsoft. You will have to write down a 50-digit number, call into
the activation center on a toll-free number that will be given to you,
read and check back the number you recorded ? and explain the
circumstances. In exchange, you will be given a 42-digit number to
type in. This will reactivate your copy of Windows.

This is made easier if Windows XP Service Pack 1 has been installed:
The system will continue to boot normally for three days, during which
time you will be able to contact the activation center via the net. If
the extra changes have been removed, or if 120 days have passed since
the original activation, you will be able to use the automatic process
once more
-----

It would seem that the start menu problems are not related to Windows
activation.

However, this brings up some interesting points for me-- has anyone
had any experience running multiple instances of XP inside virtual
machines (e.g. VMware)?  I would think the activation would cause some
severe problems with this.

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon May 23 12:25:18 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 12:25:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Java, Jikes, and Linux
In-Reply-To: <20050523182112.GA18437@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050523031929.GA16809@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<42915407.2030202@cesmail.net>
	<20050522215324.0d30d42d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<20050523182112.GA18437@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <20050523122518.683989a2.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Keith Lofstrom, on Mon, 23 May 2005 11:21:12 -0700:

> Not nearly that far along.  Apparently, to make jikes work, I must
> set some environment variables like CLASSPATH.  I have no clue where

Ah, okay, this is an easy one.  Jikes just needs to know where to find
the core java library, which is probably "$JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/rt.jar".

If you set $JAVA_HOME, jikes may be able to find it that way, but you
might as well set a system-wide $CLASSPATH that includes that JAR.  If
you do neither of those, then jikes has no way of knowing the which and
the where of it.

Here's a safer option:  write yourself a wrapper script for invoking
jikes, that sets the classpath beforehand or passes it to jikes as an
option (an alias would also work).  You can even name the script "jikes"
and put it at the front of your path, if you like.  I actually have
different jikes wrappers for different projects, since they all have
different classpaths (often different sourcepaths as well).

> me *where* to point them, or how to figure that out, would be handy.
> It is stupid to have to ask when it should be documented somewhere.

There are a couple references in the man page to "java/jre/lib/rt.jar",
but it doesn't explicitly tell you to add that in when invoking jikes. 
The basic idea is that jikes is javac compatible; but javac knows where
to find that rt.jar by the location of the executable.  jikes doesn't
have that advantage.  So yeah, explicit mention of this discrepancy
would be helpful.

--Jason

--
Do not try and fix the bug.  That's impossible.  Instead, only try to
realize the truth. . . .  There is no bug.  Then you'll see that it is
not the code that errs:  it is only the user.

On Mon, 23 May 2005, Rich Shepard wrote:
> Like riding a bike, touch typing is not forgotten once learned.

I know people that forgot how to touch type when they switched to Dvorak.

...then again, I know people who have forgotten how to ride a bicycle 
(though nearly everyone seems to have, but I'm giving them the benefit of 
the doubt).

As for learning to type without looking, I do much of my typing in the 
dark with my monitor turned off.  Most writers will tell you that the best 
way to get through a piece is to write once without revising... just let 
the words flow.  I had a terrible time not fixing things as I go.  Not 
only did I step back to fix typographical errors and minor choices in 
word, I could often be found revising entire paragraphs to fit some higher 
structural idea.  This takes time away from the project as a whole because 
the next time you sit down to write, you often go back and fix what you 
wrote last time.  Turning off the monitor was the best way I found to 
write long pieces that I knew I was going to revise later anyway.

Speaking of this, I've mentioned it before, but have never come across a 
real product like the one I seek:  I want a full-size, lightweight 
keyboard that takes a small battery (or has a rechargeable built-in) and 
some tiny flash storage device.  I want to just dump text to a file (say, 
creating a new file with a timestamp filename on each power-cycle) and 
look at it later.  Does such a thing exist?  What do you suppose it would 
cost to prototype such a thing?

(And yeah, I'd ideally want to convert a nice buckling-spring keyboard.)

J.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon May 23 20:30:42 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 20:30:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Java, Jikes, and Linux - solved
In-Reply-To: <20050523122518.683989a2.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050523031929.GA16809@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<42915407.2030202@cesmail.net>
	<20050522215324.0d30d42d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<20050523182112.GA18437@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<20050523122518.683989a2.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20050524033042.GB30217@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Mon, May 23, 2005 at 12:25:18PM -0700, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Keith Lofstrom, on Mon, 23 May 2005 11:21:12 -0700:
> 
> Ah, okay, this is an easy one.  Jikes just needs to know where to find
> the core java library, which is probably "$JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/rt.jar".
...
> Here's a safer option:  write yourself a wrapper script for invoking
> jikes, that sets the classpath beforehand or passes it to jikes as an
> option (an alias would also work).  
...

Thanks!  Now jikes works. I wrote /usr/local/bin/jikes:

  #!/bin/bash
  JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/j2re1.4.2_05
  RTJAR=$JAVA_HOME/lib/rt.jar
  /usr/bin/jikes -classpath $RTJAR  $@

Now it compiles simple programs just like javac.

I won't be doing a lot of Java coding, just enough to learn how to
read what others write and test it out, so the choice of javac or
jikes is not critical.   However, I will have other people doing
most of the coding, and I will strongly encourage portable coding
methods.  The code they write should use the least common denominator,
and compile with either javac or jikes.  

Keith

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Wed May 25 19:27:39 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Wed, 25 May 2005 19:27:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Signal Processing?
In-Reply-To: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <4295341B.5040908@cesmail.net>

You're describing what you're trying to accomplish in rather low-level
DSP detail. There are some very "user friendly" DSP packages out there.
I think Matlab is probably the best known, but it's licensed. There are
free variants, however -- Octave is for sure free and SciLab is at least
in the Debian and Gentoo repositories, although I don't know if the
SciLab license passes the strictest definitions of freedom.

If you're working with audio frequency data, you've got even more
options in the free software world. These packages will all give you
nice graphical results, spectral, lots of options, choice of windows, etc.

precisely what I need to do.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu May 26 08:38:58 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 08:38:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Signal Processing?
In-Reply-To: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20050526153858.GA32283@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, May 25, 2005 at 03:26:23PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> I am trying to figure out how to apply a Hamming (or Kaiser or various
> alternative) window to a time-domain sample prior to an FFT in order
> to more accurate characterize amplitude of an embedded signal.  I
> don't actually care _that much_ about the frequency, but I care a lot
> about the amplitude.  The literature I've found so far is a few steps
> over my head at the moment and I don't have the time to climb that
> twisting staircase of understanding now.  Can anyone point me at a
> practical treatment of how to apply these windows to data?

Lots out there.  Very simply, windowing is merely a matter of weighting
the input data before applying the FFT to it, to minimize some of the
artifacts that result from the limited sample size.  

For example, if the sample domain ranges from zero to 2pi, then raised
cosine weighting would multiply each data point in your data window by
( 1-cos(X) ), which doubles the weight of the middle points and makes
the endpoints disappear.  This flattens out the apparent frequency
response, which is important for correct conclusions in some analyses.

The different windows have different functions, a bit harder to describe
but still easy to compute, which result in different artifacts in the
result.   Whatever you do to restrict data, however, will result in
some distortion in the result.  The choice of windows should be done
with an eye towards what kinds of decisions you must make using those
results.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu May 26 08:40:51 2005
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 08:40:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Uniq and Make
In-Reply-To: <86sm0a1pyy.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050525225846.GA17171@dalsemi.com>
	<86sm0a1pyy.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20050526154051.GC17171@dalsemi.com>

On Wed, May 25, 2005 at 11:05:57PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Colin" == Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com> writes:
> 
> Colin> Anyone know how to uniqify the contents of a variable in make
> Colin> WITHOUT sorting it?
> 
> In "make"??  Can you give an example?

make has a built in command called "sort":

HFILE_SORT = $(sort $(HFILE_LIST))

that also uniq's the contents of the variable.  In doing that, it
changes the order of the elements in the variable, which allows a
trivial implementation of uniq.

In our case, the element order is important because it tells us
the order in which to do a build, so we're trying to find
a way to uniq the contents without sorting.

I can give you more details about why this has to be this way for
our system, but it gets very hairy.

Colin

It's been a long time since I did any of this, but it seemed like I used 
to convert the output of the FFT into polar coordinates. This  gives a 
histogram/array. The indices somehow map to the frequency and the value 
at each index is the amplitude for the frequency.

Laptops can have all sorts of specialized hardware and so the best thing you 
can do is go throughly research your laptop and find out every chip it has in 
so you can see if appropriate Linux drivers exist for the laptop. This is 
especially true for video and WIFI.

Is there anything special about having an AMD-64 laptop instead of a 32-bit 
Pentium M-based laptop or something like that? I've found that I don't really 
need a very high-end laptop for a laptop to be useful to me. I need email, 
web-browser, news reader, IM, word-processing/spreadsheet. For hardware 
support I need decent 2D video graphics, sound,  ethernet/WIFI support, and a 
DVD R/RW drive and that's about it.

By all means if an AMD-64 laptop suits your needs then by all means get one 
but find out the model numbers of all of the devices so you can find out if 
Linux has native driver support for everything.

I have a company issued Dell Inspiron 5150 with a 3.06Ghz P4, 1GB RAM, and 
60GB 7200 RPM hard drive. It has an nVIDIA FX5200 adapter and does pretty 
nice 3D graphics. The downside it that this laptop is very heavy, runs hotter 
than hell and I have to carry around a brick-like 130W power supply for the 
thing. 

Initially I thought it was great having such a powerful laptop but I got my 
own,  personal Inspiron 6000 with a 1.6GhZ Pentium M that runs so much cooler 
and is not a boat anchor. It has more than enough power for all of the things 
I need  a laptop for and uses a small 65W power supply and the battery life 
exceeds 4 hours. If I need more performance and better graphics I'll get a 
desktop system as it's much cheaper than a laptop.

Regards,

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net
