>From: Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com>
> In our case, the element order is important because it tells us
> the order in which to do a build, so we're trying to find
> a way to uniq the contents without sorting.

Ah. But do you actually need to `uniq` them then? If there is an output
file that Make can check the timestamps on, then Make will check the
timestamps, and skip trying to rebuild those pieces. Perhaps not as
efficient as `uniq`ing them, but certainly effective.

Hi John,

I think any of the distros should work fine for what you want. They pretty
much all offer the option to customize the amount of stuff you install.
Many of the default GUIs now are built on GNOME and KDE which might be
slow on a Pentium or Pentium II, but you can always install a different
window manager and use that instead.

One distro that is pretty cool is Gentoo -- they make it pretty easy to
build a system with binaries that are compiled for your processor.

Is the GUI friendliness crucial for you? Debian is an *excellent*
candidate for this sort of installation, but is very low on the
friendliness quotient. Notably Debian can be trimmed down to a very small
number of required packages, Debian packages tend to work, and you don't
need to do distribution release upgrades very often.

> One distro that is pretty cool is Gentoo -- they make it pretty easy to
> build a system with binaries that are compiled for your processor.

I must disagree here. On the above class of hardware the gains will be
minimal (or negative!), while it will take forever to build.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu May 26 16:32:51 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 26 May 2005 16:32:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Signal Processing?
In-Reply-To: <42960793.1010708@easystreet.com>
References: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <4295341B.5040908@cesmail.net>
	<861x7u34sb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <42960793.1010708@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <86vf55y34s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jim" == Jim Teisher <teisher at easystreet.com> writes:

Jim> Russell, It's been a long time since I did any of this, but it
Jim> seemed like I used to convert the output of the FFT into polar
Jim> coordinates. This gives a histogram/array. The indices somehow
Jim> map to the frequency and the value at each index is the amplitude
Jim> for the frequency.

Yeah, I was doing that already.  My problem erupted when I discovered
that in my sample of N measurements, unless the signal ends nicely
where it begins (in the time-domain), a discontinuity appears in the
infinite projection of the signal, and that discontinuity in turn
induces power bleed into adjacent frequency bands.  The windowing is a
way to try to deal with that.  Another way to deal with it is, if you
know in advance the dominant frequency, to pick an N that matches full
cycles of that frequency.  I am doing that too.

To illustrate in ASCII art:


+                       *                       +                       +
   +                 +  |  *                 *  |  +                 +   
     +             +    |    *             *    |    +             +     
- - - + - - - - - + - - - - - * - - - - - * - - - - - + - - - - - + - - -
       +         +      |      *         *      |      +         +       
         +     +        |        *     *        |        +     +         
            +           |           *           |           +            
                        +-----------------------+ 

In an FFT, you have a finite sample, which is assumed to repeat
forever.  If your sample consists of a whole number of waves
(represented by the asterisks) then everything is happy.  If, instead,
it looks like this:

                  +      *                       *      +                
               +     +   |  *                 *     *   |  +             
             +         + |    *             *         * |    +           
+ - - - - - + - - - - - +- - - * - - - - - * - - - - - *- - - + - - - - -
 +         +             |      *         *             |      +         
   +     +               |        *     *               |        +     + 
      +                  |           *                  |           +    
-------------------------+------------------------------+----------------

then the Fourier Transform isn't as clean and pretty.  What the
windows effectively do, is clamp down the sample at the boundaries to
zero, which attenuates some of the signal but also eliminates the
discontinuity. 

What I hadn't figured out was what the window applied to.  Was it a
moving average kind of thing?  Or did it apply to the whole sample at
once?  Turns out the latter for my purposes.  And the other thing was
how to scale the result.  This turned out to be the intuitively
obvious, you effectively divide the result by the sum of the weights
you apply.

Most of the literature I found assumed that I had read the first 8
chapters of the book, which I hadn't done, though I maybe understood
an ill-defined 5 or 6 of those chapters.  Filling in the holes led to
my difficulty.

Unga-gunga-gulunga.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Thu May 26 17:29:32 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 17:29:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] lightweight linux?
In-Reply-To: <20050526205630.13938.qmail@web52401.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050526205630.13938.qmail@web52401.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200505261729.32970.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

On Thursday 26 May 2005 1:56 pm, john morgali wrote:
> Anyone know what distro would be a good, lightweight
> distro with a gui interface, to set up a fileserver
> with on pentium 1 or pentium 2 class pc hardware?
> doesnt need major crunch power, just needs to spin a
> raid array and feed network data quickly for a home
> office.

I'm running very old RH 7.0 on a 200 Mhz Pentium. The machine serves 
essentially the purpose you're proposing, albeit without a raid array, just 1 
each, 4 Gb and 40 Gb drives. I tried upgrading to a later version and ran 
into an audio problem. My system holds .mp3 files and plays them with mpg123, 
the output of the sound card being wired to the stereo in the living room. 
With RH 8, I had problems that folks told me would be solved with the "low 
latency patch." That patch didn't work for me, and I went back to RH 7.0. I 
don't consider it a serious security problem since the machine sits inside my 
firewall, and doesn't go out on the Internet for anything.

While it does have Gnome available, I rarely log into it from it's own 
keyboard. I run Samba on it, and access files on it from my Winders machines 
and from my other Linux machine. It's also running Apache, and serves the 
house with a local web site, but neither of those require a gui. So, I'd go 
along with the other recommendations in this thread to dispense with the gui. 
Just run the services you need, and do your system maintenance from another 
machine.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

http://home.comcast.net/~rcsphoto/

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Thu May 26 19:52:33 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 19:52:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] It was not my destiny to own a Compaq notebook with Linux
In-Reply-To: <4295DE99.6090200@comcast.net>
References: <4295DE99.6090200@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <42968B71.6030504@cesmail.net>

Anything that "bleeding edge" in a laptop is bound to be prone to
issues. Think about it ... a full gigabyte of RAM, a 64-bit chip, a hard
drive, a PCI emulation chip set, a battery and advanced charging
circuitry all crammed into a tiny space and running an OS that may be at
least a couple of weeks behind the hardware. How many watts does that
monster consume?

Unless you absolutely postively for really really real need that battery
operation capability, I'll be you can find something small and light
with an Athlon 64, a real PCI subsystem, video and sound with Linux
drivers, a high-speed large hard drive, and possibly even room for more
than a GB of RAM.

I went on the Internet a couple of months ago and priced high-end AMD 64
gamer systems, and except for the RAM, which was hideously expensive,
these things were way more powerful than laptops at lower prices. And
they were perfectly willing to give you a discount if you didn't want
Windows loaded on it. When I'm ready for an AMD 64, I'll go with a
free-standing plug in model, and when my current (dual booted
XP/Gentoo/Athlon XP) laptop croaks, I'll get something cheap to replace it.

From teisher at easystreet.com  Thu May 26 20:14:17 2005
From: teisher at easystreet.com (Jim Teisher)
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 20:14:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Digital Signal Processing?
In-Reply-To: <86vf55y34s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86acmj2b8w.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<4295341B.5040908@cesmail.net>	<861x7u34sb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<42960793.1010708@easystreet.com> <86vf55y34s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <42969089.80505@easystreet.com>

Russell,

Are you doing coherent sampling?

Using this formula:

    Fs / N = Ft / M

If you aren't, I can try to explain it.

There other area that could be causing problems is the the test 
equipment you are using for sampling. If your test equipment isn't very 
accurate in sampling the jitter in the test equipment could be the cause 
of your problems. The speed of the sampling is not as important as the 
accuracy of the sampling.

Nice ASCII art.

Jim

In-Reply-To: <86fyw9xpcx.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

	<4295341B.5040908@cesmail.net>	<861x7u34sb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<42960793.1010708@easystreet.com>	<86vf55y34s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<42969089.80505@easystreet.com> <86fyw9xpcx.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <4296B19B.7050200@easystreet.com>

Fs / N = Ft / M

This is a relationship that must be maintained when you are making your measurements. 
Fs = sampling frequency
Ft = test signal frequency
N  = total number of samples
M  = total number cycles.

M and N must be mutually prime. This means they can't have any common factors. N must be a power of 2 for your FFT to work, and this means that M will always be odd.

You must fiddle with these values to get the Fs and Ft to about 7 or 8 significant digits. Your test equipment has a sampling resolution which will effect what you can select for Ft. Failing to keep this relationship can account for the glitch that you see at the end of your waveform, and add a bunch of high frequency noise.

Jim

Options +Includes
  AddType text/html .inc
  AddOutputFilter INCLUDES .inc

I've done this and restarted Apache, and created some test web page and

changing .inc to .shtml like all of the examples but that didn't help.

<html>
<title>Include Test Page</title>
<body>
If this works we should see the date printed on the page<p>
<!--#echo var="DATE_LOCAL" -->
<!--#include virtual="test.inc" -->
</body>
</html>

test.inc is just a simple file with one line of text to display in it.  
 From what I know of SSI this should work.  Any ideas of what I'm 
missing here?

Thanks

On Thu, 2005-05-26 at 07:35 -0700, John Jason Jordan wrote:

> Considering what I went through with the R4000 and now this, I can only 
> conclude that I was not meant to own an Athlon-64 notebook with Linux. 
> <sigh>

May I ask why you want an Athlon 64 so badly?  They might be the best
performance for your money, but they're very new--new enough that I
haven't had my hands on any.  While Linux has been on 64-bit platforms
for a decade or so, they've been supported by distros mainly as a server
platform and generally something of a second-class citizen to ia32.

Add that to the fact that laptops themselves, with their dizzying array
of specialized hardware, have themselves been second-class citizens;
compound further the fact that you yourself are a neophyte and you have
a recipe for disaster.

Why not a nice Pentium M system with an ATI video chipset and Orinoco
wireless?

Wil

From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri May 27 14:02:08 2005
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 14:02:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Losing Command Of My Terminal
In-Reply-To: <20050527135222.15f52f88.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050527103749.4b44d31b.jason@vancleve.com>
	<20050527175013.GC29644@rauhaus.org>
	<20050527135222.15f52f88.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20050527210208.GB32546@rauhaus.org>

* Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> [050527 13:52]:
> Quoth Stafford A. Rau, on Fri, 27 May 2005 10:50:14 -0700:
> 
> > Is it an ssh session? If so, you can type ~. to force close your end
> > of the session.
> 
> Yeah, ssh.  Where do I type the tilde?  Is that part of the ssh command?

For some reason, when you exit from the remote server, your local ssh
session doesn't get the hangup signal.

When that happens, just type ~. in the hung terminal window. You won't
see your keystrokes, but the ~ (tilde) is the escape character for your
local ssh session, and period means close the session. That should drop
you back to your local shell prompt in that Eterm window.

--Stafford

From johnxj at comcast.net  Sat May 28 08:25:18 2005
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 08:25:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: It was not my destiny to own a Compaq notebook with
	Linux
In-Reply-To: <42976211.8070500@axpr.net>
References: <4295DE99.6090200@comcast.net>	<1117216409.3988.8.camel@denk.nakedape.cc>
	<42976211.8070500@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <42988D5E.1010906@comcast.net>

More Hewlett-Packard Weirditude

So, having decided to return the Compaq R4000 I called for an RMA and 
simultaneously ordered an R3470. As previously mentioned, HP got the 
credit card stuff screwed up and by the time I got it straightened out, 
the R3470 was out of stock.

I spent the next couple days looking for an R3000 series. There aren't 
very many available at online merchants, and eBay is a bit scary for a 
laptop. So about noon yesterday I decided to buy the R3340 which is 
still available on hpshopping.com in their refurbished area. Not quite 
as good a deal as the R3470, but still better than I could get anywhere 
else. Both the R3470 and the R3340 have nVidia video and there is ample 
documentation at Linux on Laptops for getting the video to work at 1280 
x 800.

The sales dude had told me that it might not make it in time to be 
shipped out on Friday. So about 2 pm I went to hpshopping.com and 
checked on the order. And once again I saw "payment not authorized." So 
this time, before calling HP, I called the manager at my bank, who knows 
me. Together we went on a conference call to the bank's card approval 
department. When I gave the guy at the card approval department the 
exact amount he verified that the bank had approved it a little after 
noon that day. Furthermore, he indicated that they had approved the 
previous purchase right after I had made it a few days earlier. He also 
verified that there was nothing whatsoever wrong with my account, no 
holds or restraints of any kind.

Armed with this information I called HP. I insisted on being escalated 
to someone who could straighten things out. This got me to a fellow who 
identified himself as a "supervisor" with the name "Tim." Tim proceeded 
to explain that HP uses "industry standard" practices to scrutinize 
phone and internet credit card transactions to prevent indentity theft 
and fraud. He assured me he could straighten things out if I could just 
answer a few questions. "Sure," I said, "no problem." He said HP had 
developed a series of questions designed to protect their customers from 
illegal practices. I told him to go ahead.

 The first question was "given the first names Edward, Josh, Samuel, 
Michael and William, which did I most identify with?" I am not making 
this up.

"What questions are coming next?" I asked, "ink blots?"

I declined to answer such a silly question and we had some discussion 
whether I was willing to continue. Finally I agreed to listen the the 
second question. This turned out to be another set of first names, again 
asking which I most identified with. But this time one of the names was 
John, so I laughed and told him my answer was John. "Fine," he said, 
apologizing again for the inconvenience and assuring me that this series 
of questions was "industry standard" and that HP took security very 
seriously to protect its customers.

We proceeded to the third question, which asked me for the billing 
address on my credit card. For about the fourth time I repeated it, 
including the nine-digit zip code, hoping that would indicate that I 
wasn't someone who found a credit card lying on the sidewalk. He thanked 
me for the answer and repeated again the corporate spin about how sorry 
he was for inconveniencing me and how seriously HP took security 
matters. Then asked me the fourth question, which was "what is your 
social security number?"

Now, as anyone who met met at the Clinic and has read my Linux questions 
here, clearly I have some seriously dumb moments. But I'm not totally 
stupid. I decided this was not only the last straw, but it was time to 
inform him that I had already contacted my bank and that the charge had 
been approved hours earlier. I told him that no way was he getting my 
social security number. Then I added the details about the conference 
call the bank manager and I had had a few minutes earlier. I gave him 
her direct telephone number. And then I told him our interview was over. 
I further added that he could do whatever he wanted, but if the website 
did not show the transaction was approved by 4 pm I was calling the bank 
and blocking the transaction. And that I was then going to Fry's to buy 
a Sony. And then I hung up without waiting for a response.

I checked again a little after four and the website still says "not 
authorized." So I called the manager back and explained what had gone 
on. She couldn't believe my report of the conversation. We made another 
conference call to the card approval department. Normally once 
authorization is given you can't undo the transaction. But having the 
branch manager on the phone got past that little difficulty. Having a 
substantial account at the bank also helped. :)

There is only one conclusion we could reach. HP is pissed that I 
returned the R4000 (for which they refunded the full $1428 I pad for 
it), and has blocked me.

I really do like the Compaq R3000 series. Love everything about it. But 
I guess I won't be buying one, unless perhaps a good deal comes up on 
eBay. Later today I'm going to go to Fry's and check out laptops some more.

I've checked out Linux on Laptops and read a great deal about which 
brands are best. Everyone says Thinkpads are great with Linux, but 
they're just too ugly for my artistic side. But at least I have mostly 
given up the idea of getting a 64-bit laptop and running a 64-bit distro 
on it. I definitely want something that is 15.4 widescreen at 1280 x 
800, a gig of RAM and as fast a CPU as I can get. Since I'm back to 
square one with the shopping, I'm open to suggestions.

I always knew installing Linux would present challenges. I didn't 
realize buying the computer would be even harder. :(

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat May 28 10:10:02 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 10:10:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Death in the open source community
In-Reply-To: <86ll60wkz5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0505271644550.11498@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
	<86ll60wkz5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20050528171002.GA23448@gate.kl-ic.com>


Losing Chris reminds us that we are all mortal.  Some of us are
maintaining open source projects, and many of us have information
and records well encrypted on our own machines.  While it is tragic
to lose the individual, the tragedy is compounded when others depend
on the information we keep secure.  And as Linux users, some of us
keep our data *very* secure.

In March 2004, the original author of Dirvish, JW Schultz, was
murdered for witnessing a crime.   The Dirvish CVS tree was stored
on his encrypted disks, and was unrecoverable by the best forensic
computer scientists.  His death was a terrible loss to the development
of Dirvish, and the CVS information took months to reconstruct.

It might be helpful to set up some sort of "information escrow"
mechanism for PLUG members.  For example, I could regularly construct
a file containing all my secret information, encrypt it with my
public key, and regularly send it to special email accounts maintained
by a few trusted individuals. 

Separately, I could send printed fragments of my private keys to
other trusted individuals.  Some mechanism where some fraction of
those key fragments can be combined to produce a whole one would 
allow, say, 5 individuals out of 8 to combine their key fragments
and get access to my data.  

Setting up a tested mechanism for this might help our project teams
and our families recover after our own death or disablement.   This
possibility is only one drunk driver away.  Anyone interested in
setting up such a mechanism?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

You mentioned getting a Sony at Fry's.  Don't get a Sony.  They're full
of odd proprietary devices that only "work" (er, sort of) under Windows
because they don't have Linux drivers, e.g., PCMCIA stuff and WinModems.

And in general, don't buy a notebook at Fry's.  Unless you enjoy paying
more than things are worth, that is.  Better to find a used notebook on
eBay that's got the specs you want, offered by a reputable, high-volume
seller that takes Visa/MC (so you can cancel the charge if you need to).

> Everyone says Thinkpads are great with Linux, but 
> they're just too ugly for my artistic side.

Notebooks are just tools, not fashion accessories.  If you want a really
cool fashion statement, get an iBook (or whatever Apple's selling now).
After all, Linus has an Apple desktop system, so it's gotta be so cool.
But I'm just kidding.  An iBook might be hard to get working with Linux.

Sorry about your experience with HP....

There is a writeup on it at

http://www.caprinae-ascendant.net/foss/linux-on-sager.php

You can buy it without an OS, and the writeup leads me to believe that 
it might be a pretty good Linux laptop. It's just kind of spendy. Fitted 
out the way I want it, it comes to about $1800 or so, depending on 
retailer. And it has the mobile Pentium M 750, which is not as fast as I 
wish it had. And worse, there is no way for me to go look at one to see 
what it looks like. Sager does offer 30-day no-questions return policy, 
though. On the other hand, I haven't had the best experiences with 
return policies lately, now have I?

From ehem at m5p.com  Sat May 28 13:46:12 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 13:46:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Losing Command Of My Terminal
In-Reply-To: <20050528152544.4AB56439F@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200505282046.j4SKkCHi074518@m5p.com>

>From: Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>
> Quoth Stafford A. Rau, on Fri, 27 May 2005 14:02:08 -0700:
> 
> > When that happens, just type ~. in the hung terminal window. You won't
> 
> Cool, thanks.  I'll have to just etch that one into my brain.

Three notes on this. The tilde must follow a newline. Not generally a
problem, as most of the time you're only interested in one of the tilde
commands after having pressed enter, but something to be aware of.
Second, there are a couple other tilde commands, notably ~? lists them
and gives quick usage information on all of them. Finally, tilde escapes
itself, if actually need to type a tilde after a newline, you need to
type tilde twice.

Personally I dislike using ~. as it points to something on the other end
thinking you're still active. Most likely this would mean something on a
tunneled connection is active.

>  > gotta be so cool. But I'm just kidding. An iBook might be hard to
>  > get working with Linux.
> 
> Actually, I think don't think Apples are particularly attractive. 
> Rounded corners are so last millennium. And I don't want my whole life 
> in white. The only way to use an Apple properly is in a sterile white 
> room, at a desk with a white tablecloth and a rosebud in a vase. Plus, 
> they're horribly expensive if you want one with some horespower.

Depends on how much horsepower you need. Remember, they're using PPC
which doesn't need the high clock speed of the Pentiums to get a heck of
a lot done, though I do understand that PPC might actually be a problem
for you. They also place emphasis on getting pretty good battery life,
which tends to mean a slower processor that uses less power. If you look
they're fairly competitive on price with PC laptops. No worse than Sony
at least.

The only issue would be the graphics chips. As with the PC world, taking
full advantage of the modern graphics chips requires a bit of software
from either ATi or nVIDIA, and I don't believe they're supporting
Linux-PPC. Making partial use, and merely getting 2D acceleration should
be easy though.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat May 28 14:01:38 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 14:01:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Buying Laptops (was HP wierdness...)
In-Reply-To: <4298BED1.9040300@comcast.net>
References: <20050528152544.28F12438B@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<1117304263.8281.139.camel@griffin> <4298BED1.9040300@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20050528210138.GD23933@gate.kl-ic.com>


Laptop opinions:  The speed of a laptop is measured in human terms
by how long you have to wait to complete a slow calculation.  Worst
case, this is the field service turnaround time... :-(  Thus, the
responsiveness of the company supplying (and eventually repairing)
the laptop should be a big part of your decision, and that is measured
by the experiences of others.

Thus, I am really bummed that HP treated John so ... weirdly.  After
watching IBM's Thinkpad service erode from outstanding to mediocre,
I was hoping that HP would retain a clue.  Keep looking, I guess...

Laptops cram an enormous amount of technology into a tiny case, which
gets much more physical abuse than a typical desktop.  Something has
to give, and it is usually some combination of price and reliability. 
So plan on repairs about once a year, get the extended warranty. 
Make sure that the service organization can find and repair problems,
and do so quickly.  IBM used to be able to ship and repair a laptop
door-to-door in 36 hours, which is why I once was quite loyal to
them, in spite of their higher price.

Plan on buying extra AC adapters, unless you are fond of crawling 
under furniture.  You will probably want a CD-RW so you can write
Knoppix disks for strangers.  It is handy to have a removable hard
drive cage, so when you inevitably send the machine in for service,
you can keep your data.  I have Ultrabay drives for my thinkpads,
so I can swap CD-RW, floppy, and second hard drive.

One thing that I don't want is built-in modems and built-in wifi,
Linux drivers or not.  Modems connect to phone wires, which are
often exposed to lightning and other nasties.  I prefer to connect
through an easily replaceable PCMCIA card.  Built-in wifi chipsets
are usually 20mW or under, and often have driver problems, while
PCMCIA cards such as the Senao 200mW Prism2 card have good driver
support and much greater reach.  And when you eject the card, you
can be sure that the network is disconnected;  this is harder to
verify with software-controlled built-in Wifi.

But before buying anything, ask another Linux user who has the
model you are contemplating.  That is why the Linux for Laptops
website is useful.  Life is too short to spend it chasing down
X drivers for oddball video chipsets.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Keith Lofstrom wrote:

>Losing Chris reminds us that we are all mortal.  Some of us are
>maintaining open source projects, and many of us have information
>and records well encrypted on our own machines.  While it is tragic
>to lose the individual, the tragedy is compounded when others depend
>on the information we keep secure.  And as Linux users, some of us
>keep our data *very* secure.
>
>In March 2004, the original author of Dirvish, JW Schultz, was
>murdered for witnessing a crime.   The Dirvish CVS tree was stored
>on his encrypted disks, and was unrecoverable by the best forensic
>computer scientists.  His death was a terrible loss to the development
>of Dirvish, and the CVS information took months to reconstruct.
>
>It might be helpful to set up some sort of "information escrow"
>mechanism for PLUG members.  For example, I could regularly construct
>a file containing all my secret information, encrypt it with my
>public key, and regularly send it to special email accounts maintained
>by a few trusted individuals. 
>
>Separately, I could send printed fragments of my private keys to
>other trusted individuals.  Some mechanism where some fraction of
>those key fragments can be combined to produce a whole one would 
>allow, say, 5 individuals out of 8 to combine their key fragments
>and get access to my data.  
>
>Setting up a tested mechanism for this might help our project teams
>and our families recover after our own death or disablement.   This
>possibility is only one drunk driver away.  Anyone interested in
>setting up such a mechanism?
>
>Keith

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sat May 28 21:08:50 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

(Top posting moved to bottom posting for clarity)

> Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> >Losing Chris reminds us that we are all mortal.  Some of us are
> >maintaining open source projects, and many of us have information
> >and records well encrypted on our own machines.  While it is tragic
> >to lose the individual, the tragedy is compounded when others depend
> >on the information we keep secure.  And as Linux users, some of us
> >keep our data *very* secure.
> >
> >In March 2004, the original author of Dirvish, JW Schultz, was
> >murdered for witnessing a crime.   The Dirvish CVS tree was stored
> >on his encrypted disks, and was unrecoverable by the best forensic
> >computer scientists.  His death was a terrible loss to the development
> >of Dirvish, and the CVS information took months to reconstruct.
> >
> >It might be helpful to set up some sort of "information escrow"
> >mechanism for PLUG members.  For example, I could regularly construct
> >a file containing all my secret information, encrypt it with my
> >public key, and regularly send it to special email accounts maintained
> >by a few trusted individuals. 
> >
> >Separately, I could send printed fragments of my private keys to
> >other trusted individuals.  Some mechanism where some fraction of
> >those key fragments can be combined to produce a whole one would 
> >allow, say, 5 individuals out of 8 to combine their key fragments
> >and get access to my data.  
> >
> >Setting up a tested mechanism for this might help our project teams
> >and our families recover after our own death or disablement.   This
> >possibility is only one drunk driver away.  Anyone interested in
> >setting up such a mechanism?

On Sat, May 28, 2005 at 03:04:28PM -0700, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky wrote:
> This should be in your will and available to your attorney. If you don't
> *have* a will and an attorney who understands what this means, get both.
 
Actually, the four letter sequence "this" appears in many places in my
will.  I assume Ed is be referring to some antecedent phrase, which he
neglected to define.  

I am guessing that by "this", Ed is referring not to my whole posting,
suggesting one example of a secure key escrow mechanism, but to some
kind of actual expression of my private encryption key, in my will
document, mediated by my non-technical lawyer.  However, since wills
are typically maintained as unencrypted text editor documents on
insecure desktop computers, printed in multiple copies, and kept on
file in the county of residence during probate (available for public
scrutiny),  that guess describes a silly way to go about things.

Perhaps Ed's unclear reference to "this" refers to some other part
of my posting, and I hope he can concretely identify that for me
so I can make some sense of his statement.


Rich's reply, suggesting I just keep my open source projects on an
unencrypted disk, misses the point.  People typically keep lots of
things on a single disk, and some more paranoid folk may apply
encryption to their whole disk (as JW did).  I do not myself, now,
but will do so if security threats increase.  CVS aside, important
information on my disks *is* encrypted, and some of that information
should be available to my wife, friends or certain others upon my
demise.  A key escrow mechanism, shared with knowledgeable friends,
would help.

Now it might be that most people don't give a shit what happens to
others after they pass away, perhaps because there is nobody who 
cares about them or the information they maintain.  But the open
source community contains some very generous and empathetic people,
not just social misfit code jockeys, and it is that empathy I am
attempting to engage here.  What are we going to do to protect our
data, yet make it potentially accessable to those we care about?

Keith

Yup, you need to 'mkinitrd...' with the proper options.

On my system, if I just run mkinitrd without any options, it gives me a
command line example for the currently running kernel, and that's easy
enough to go by to figure it out.

After making the initrd, add it to your grub stanza for that kernel.

Keith is making perfect sense to me...

It's the nature of life today that many of us (myself included)
necessarily keep important things encrypted.  We don't want other people
to have access to these things.  Think of encrypted files as a
more-secure safety deposit box at the local bank (banks still do have
these somewhere, right?).  We put important documents in the magic
little box that keeps everybody else out.

Some of these important things are things that need to be released upon
death to close relatives, friends, and collegues.  For instance, I'd
want my GoDaddy password to be given to Alan Hicks if I died, because I
own the Slackbook domain and he's the Slackbook maintainer.  I'd like
him to be able to transfer the domain to himself without such hassle if
I pass away.

Does this make sense so far?

Keith is trying to come up with a mechanism to allow information like
that to be released upon death... what if I get hit by a bus tomorrow
(quite unlikely, we don't have busses down here)?  What mechanism might
allow Alan access to my password?

I like the idea of trusting a few close friends with bits of the puzzle,
so only working together could they unlock the data... trusting a
majority wouldn't be comprimised or decide to comprimise things
themselves.  However, I wonder if there's a better way.

Keith was, I believe, trying to get some constructive discussion going.
 How do we solve the problem?

I must agree entrusting the entire puzzle to a lawyer who likely doesn't
understand the concepts behind it is not a viable solution.

My two cents.

Rob

you.  make install won't even work on an ia64 machine (target not 
found).  Didn't work for me on Yellowdog either, but I'm not really a 
PPC person.

AthlonRob wrote:
> It's the nature of life today that many of us (myself included)
> necessarily keep important things encrypted.  We don't want other people
> to have access to these things.  Think of encrypted files as a
> more-secure safety deposit box at the local bank (banks still do have
> these somewhere, right?).  We put important documents in the magic
> little box that keeps everybody else out.

Yes, but I wouldn't put every piece of paper that I own in a safe 
deposit box. Just the important documents. I certainly wouldn't put the 
source code for an Open Source project there, unless it was an offsite 
backup for DR purposes. I would not do it to keep that document secret.

And I would have plans in place in advance for how the people who would 
need access to those important documents in the safe deposit box would 
get to them. That is not exactly a new concept.

Putting your encryption key inside of a safe deposit box with 
instructions for who should have access to it if you passed would 
actually be one way to handle the scenario Keith mentions.

> Some of these important things are things that need to be released upon
> death to close relatives, friends, and collegues.  For instance, I'd
> want my GoDaddy password to be given to Alan Hicks if I died, because I
> own the Slackbook domain and he's the Slackbook maintainer.  I'd like
> him to be able to transfer the domain to himself without such hassle if
> I pass away.

It seems again that there are easier solutions for this. Like moving the 
name to a separate account and sharing the password with him.

> Does this make sense so far?
> 
> Keith is trying to come up with a mechanism to allow information like
> that to be released upon death... what if I get hit by a bus tomorrow
> (quite unlikely, we don't have busses down here)?  What mechanism might
> allow Alan access to my password?

And what if one of the 8 people who has a piece of your encryption key 
loses it?

> I like the idea of trusting a few close friends with bits of the puzzle,
> so only working together could they unlock the data... trusting a
> majority wouldn't be comprimised or decide to comprimise things
> themselves. 

You guys are obviously free to pursue this if you want to, but I just 
feel like you are making things much more complicated than they need to be.

If the data is not something that needs to be encrypted, like a CVS tree 
for an Open Source project, then I just would not encrypt it. I think 
people who are working on an Open Source project together should make 
sure their data is shared, not kept secret. If there is only one copy on 
someone's encrypted hard drive, then that's a problem if the drive fails 
too. You should certainly have some sort of DR plan involving offsite 
backups from wherever the CVS server is.

In Keith's followup he makes it sound like he is concerned about more 
personal data. If you can't trust a friend or family member enough to 
give them some sort of access to that, even access where they at least 
need to jump through some hoops first (like through a lawyer), then I'm 
not sure what to tell you. Frankly I would trust my own family members 
with the key to retrieve information that I needed to encrypt more than 
I would people that I know through PLUG. Nothing personal, I've met some 
great people through the group, but if the info is important enough to 
encrypt it I would want to entrust that to someone closer to me.

If you do want to break up your encryption key and give pieces of it to 
several people, then by all means do. That should be pretty easy for 
anyone who is familiar with their encryption software to do, I'm not 
sure why that needs the participation of PLUG somehow.

And Keith, someone who disagrees about the need for what you propose is 
not necessarily lacking empathy or compassion, that suggestion seems to 
be a bit of a low blow.


Rich



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun May 29 12:38:42 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Grub with a new kernel
In-Reply-To: <429A0455.4080504@axpr.net>

	<1688.207.118.124.114.1117385959.squirrel@hood.dimstar.net>
	<86hdgmuewc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <429A0455.4080504@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <86d5r9vn3x.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "AthlonRob" == AthlonRob  <athlonrob at axpr.net> writes:

Russell> I don't have Carla's book, so I don't know what instructions
Russell> she provides, but a few things occur to me:

Russell> a) "make menuconfig" works for configuring a kernel build
Russell> without X.  It is what I usually use, even with X.

AthlonRob> Do people still use those X thingies?  I couldn't imagine
AthlonRob> using anything but oldconfig and menuconfig these days.

Yeah, that's my routine too.

Russell> b) did you remember to "make install" and "make
Russell> modules_install"?

AthlonRob> make install?

AthlonRob> Where does it put the kernel?  What does it name it?  What
AthlonRob> does it do if a kernel is already there with that name?

./Makefile names the kernel using $VERSION, $PATCHLEVEL, $SUBLEVEL and
$EXTRAVERSION.  If you want to maintain more distinction than the
defaults, the $EXTRAVERSION is probably what you want to modify.

"make install" ultimately calls, e.g.:

  $ sh /aux2/src/linux-2.6.11/arch/i386/boot/install.sh 2.6.11.7 arch/i386/boot/bzImage System.map ""

which, in turn, calls:

  ~/bin/installkernel 

or 

  /sbin/installkernel

if they exist.  Otherwise, it moves existing vmlinuz and System.map to
.old and plops the new ones down.

Debian's default /sbin/installkernel puts vmlinuz-x.y.z.extra
System.map-x.y.z.extra and config-x.y.z.extra in /boot, points
nonversion'd symlinks at them and then calls mkboot which does the
right thing for LILO, ELILO, Grub, etc.  In the case of Grub, it is
just a reminder to edit your /boot/grub/menu.lst.

AthlonRob> Do people actually regularly use make install on a kernel?

Yes.  I do anyway.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun May 29 14:28:25 2005

AthlonRob wrote:
>It's the nature of life today that many of us (myself included)
>necessarily keep important things encrypted.  We don't want other people
>to have access to these things.  Think of encrypted files as a
>more-secure safety deposit box at the local bank (banks still do have
>these somewhere, right?).  We put important documents in the magic
>little box that keeps everybody else out.
 
On Sun, May 29, 2005 at 11:51:32AM -0700, Rich Burroughs wrote:
> Yes, but I wouldn't put every piece of paper that I own in a safe 
> deposit box. Just the important documents. I certainly wouldn't put the 
> source code for an Open Source project there, unless it was an offsite 
> backup for DR purposes. I would not do it to keep that document secret.
> 
> And I would have plans in place in advance for how the people who would 
> need access to those important documents in the safe deposit box would 
> get to them. That is not exactly a new concept.
> 
> Putting your encryption key inside of a safe deposit box with 
> instructions for who should have access to it if you passed would 
> actually be one way to handle the scenario Keith mentions.

Keith responds:
Rich, you have surely heard of encrypted file systems?  While I do not
consider them justified by present security threats, other people I
respect do.  It makes no sense to finely divide information into 
"secure" and "insecure", when the same security process can be spread
over all the data.  Portions of that data may be publically accessable,
like 4 of the Wikis and 2 of the Subversion trees on my server.  Other
portions are much more tightly secured.  It is good general practice to
forbid all access, then open specific holes for access to some things.
That is the way I tried to design my server.  This makes most of the
data, and the underlying structure, inaccessable without the magic keys.

Now, pretend I get hit by a bus - or I'm visiting Athlon Rob, and I'm
hit by a log truck or tractor.  My wife is smart enough to spend two
years learning to be a sysadmin and run my servers after me, but
chances are she has a few other things to worry about.  What happens
with my computers?  My offsite colo?  Who moderates the mailing
lists?  Who does what I used to do?  At very bare minimum, who does
she trust to transition the systems and data to other maintainers? 
She, at least, has met some of you folks.  But which of you should
she trust, and how should she decide that?

Spending some time coming up with a scalable and tested solution,
rather than a few ad-hoc measures, might go a long way to help her
or others faced with a terrible loss and a lack of technical skill.
Some of you fellows are young, and have not seen very many of these
tragedies yet.  My wife and I have helped enough widows and others
through disasters to know that ad hoc solutions can cause a lot of
unnecessary grief.


Rich Burroughs asks:
> And what if one of the 8 people who has a piece of your encryption key 
> loses it?

A.Rob writes:
>I like the idea of trusting a few close friends with bits of the puzzle,
>so only working together could they unlock the data... trusting a
>majority wouldn't be comprimised or decide to comprimise things
>themselves. 

Keith writes:
The way these things work is to divide the puzzle up so that, say, 5 
out of 8 partial keys can be used to generate a complete key.  There
are known techniques for this, suitable for any M out of N requirement.
It is precisely because people move around and situations change that
I would like to design a less ad hoc structure.  

I could appoint a "technical executor" in my will, and keep that person
apprised of my current situation, keys, whatever.  But, I am in the
midst of being executor for my mother's estate, and even that well
trodden path is fraught with surprises, even though we spent hundreds
of hours preparing before she passed away.  A few of my friends have
been executors for the estates of other technical friends, and technology
adds a whole level of complication and surprises that is very hard to
predict in detail before the fact.  This stuff does not become simple
simply by unthinkingly labelling it so.  

This is why I would like to work with a group of similarly concerned
individuals to design such a process, systematically.  More heads are
better than fewer, and when the process is tested, it will improve as
the survivors gain experience.  More people involved means more
experience, faster.  Careless motorcyclists and 90yo's welcome! :-)


Rich Burroughs writes:
> In Keith's followup he makes it sound like he is concerned about more 
> personal data. If you can't trust a friend or family member enough to 
> give them some sort of access to that, even access where they at least 
> need to jump through some hoops first (like through a lawyer), then I'm 
> not sure what to tell you. Frankly I would trust my own family members 
> with the key to retrieve information that I needed to encrypt more than 
> I would people that I know through PLUG. Nothing personal, I've met some 
> great people through the group, but if the info is important enough to 
> encrypt it I would want to entrust that to someone closer to me.

Keith writes:
You are conflating trustworthiness, interest, judgement, and capability.   
My wife is trustworthy, but her technical judgement, interest, and
capability are all low.  She runs Linux (yay!), but I handle the
security details for her ("Time to think up a new password, sweetheart!"
"Again?  But we did that last year, honey").  She can read a 600 page
medical text, but balks at a man page.  I have stopped her from sending
out mailings to groups with everyone CC'd instead of BCC'd.  I have
helped her choose good passwords.  She will need technical help after
I am gone, and she won't find it in the phone book. 

In our case, we have socialized with enough PLUG folk that she knows
people that can help with personal disaster recovery.  But will she
use them, rather than, say, my Windoze-zealot lawyer brother-in-law? 
These things are best decided in advance, formally, and given that
any particular person I appoint as a technical successor could move
or otherwise be unavailable, I would prefer to appoint a trustworthy,
picked group.

Now, try to put all the language for that in a will.  Ever seen an
attorney write a will?  They typically start with something called
the "West Law CD" and crib 12 pages of text.  Then they start writing
their own stuff, based on poorly remembered bits of law school 
lectures, and often at odds with the laws currently on the books.
I am currently straightening out one such mess, and it will probably
cost $5K and a couple of court appearances to fix.  And that is for
a simple special needs trust, well described in the literature.  Five
minutes with a magazine article or a web page, and my mother's bozo
lawyer could have written a better will.  What would these guys know
about moving DNS registrations, or securing access to a colo machine,
or splitting off open source projects to trusted lieutenants?  There
are a small handful of technically competent lawyers out there, and
they typically don't write wills.

Rich Burroughs writes:
> If you do want to break up your encryption key and give pieces of it to 
> several people, then by all means do. That should be pretty easy for 
> anyone who is familiar with their encryption software to do, I'm not 
> sure why that needs the participation of PLUG somehow.

Keith writes:
It does not need the participation of "PLUG", especially since PLUG
is not a legal entity.  It could benefit from the participation of
specific individuals in this group, hence I mention it here.  Rich
has made it clear that he is not one of those individuals, Athlon
Rob possibly might be.  There may be others of you who may also see
the need, and I would like to hear from you.  The rest of you can
hit the N key, and I will think nothing bad about you!

Rich Burroughs writes:
> And Keith, someone who disagrees about the need for what you propose is 
> not necessarily lacking empathy or compassion, that suggestion seems to 
> be a bit of a low blow.

I assume this is in reference to my paragraph:
> Now it might be that most people don't give a shit what happens to
> others after they pass away, perhaps because there is nobody who
> cares about them or the information they maintain.  But the open
> source community contains some very generous and empathetic people,
> not just social misfit code jockeys, and it is that empathy I am
> attempting to engage here.  What are we going to do to protect our
> data, yet make it potentially accessable to those we care about?

Keith writes:
Rich, if you read what I wrote carefully, you will notice that I did not
accuse you of lacking empathy or compassion.  Without more data, the
only faults I can accuse you of are less-than-perfect reading skills,
and a bit of irritability, both problems I share with you.  :-)

Keith

From ckonstan at lunarlogic.com  Sun May 29 14:32:10 2005
From: ckonstan at lunarlogic.com (Carlos Konstanski)

I'd say you need to open the kernel config in menuconfig again and
do the following:

     - Drill down to this menu level: Device Drivers > Block Devices

     - Have a look at this setting: RAM Disk Support.

I use no initrd image and haven't for a long time.  This setting is
turned off for me.  This is on a 2.6.11.6 kernel (shamefully out of
date).  Reading the help for this setting, it isn't clear whether it
is still important to turn off in the case of initrd-less boot.  In
the 2.4 days, there were similarly named settings that did matter.

I looked through the whole menuconfig and I see nothing else that
would pertain.  Initramfs Source Files is somewhat related but not close
enough to count.

Your original question - "What's wrong with my root?" - is best
answered if we knew what your partitions looked like.  But if we
assume the other 2 boot options work, that's not a real issue here.

Does this new kernel know how to read your hard drive without initrd
support?  You need IDE, SATA or SCSI drivers.  Look at Device Drivers
> Block Devices > ATA/ATAPI/MFM/RLL support > Include IDE/ATA-2 DISK
support (CONFIG_BLK_DEV_IDEDISK).  Make sure it is turned on and the
appropriate chipset options are turned on too.

It's gotta be something that was compiled as a module in your old
kernel that is needed to read the hard drive, dontcha think?  Make
sure you change "M"s to "*"s in this area of the kernel config.

Carlos

From ron at Opus1.COM  Sun May 29 16:53:16 2005
From: ron at Opus1.COM (Ronald Chmara)

	<86mzqeug6o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <429A033C.70507@axpr.net>
	<429A0F34.8020009@paranoid.org> <20050529212825.GA19729@gate.kl-ic.com>

On May 29, 2005, at 2:28 PM, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> Now, pretend I get hit by a bus - or I'm visiting Athlon Rob, and I'm
> hit by a log truck or tractor.  My wife is smart enough to spend two
> years learning to be a sysadmin and run my servers after me, but
> chances are she has a few other things to worry about.  What happens
> with my computers?  My offsite colo?  Who moderates the mailing
> lists?  Who does what I used to do?  At very bare minimum, who does
> she trust to transition the systems and data to other maintainers?
> She, at least, has met some of you folks.  But which of you should
> she trust, and how should she decide that?
>
> Spending some time coming up with a scalable and tested solution,
> rather than a few ad-hoc measures, might go a long way to help her
> or others faced with a terrible loss and a lack of technical skill.
> Some of you fellows are young, and have not seen very many of these
> tragedies yet.  My wife and I have helped enough widows and others
> through disasters to know that ad hoc solutions can cause a lot of
> unnecessary grief.

I have quite a bit of experience in such domains, where one company 
went through no less than 8 master "root" employees (as they were 
considered, a CTO, VP of IT, various SysAds, etc.) in 3 years. Some 
left on good terms, others were escorted from the building while a 
cascade of decryption and password changing routines occurred in the 
background (we had it down to five minutes of shifting and transfer 
when I finally left). I'm also the designated executor/guardian for a 
number of complex situations in my family, ranging from living wills to 
hidden monetary sources to child custody. There's certainly a lot to 
consider.

In addition to the minimal amount of tech involved, the really heavy 
lifting is more about establishing policy. Sure, having passwords and 
encryption keys stored in a trusted place (say, a safety deposit box or 
whatever) is a start, but the real challenges are about *who* gets 
access, *how* they get access, *when* they get access, and *what* they 
are supposed to do with that access.

Some lessons learned so far:
1) There should always be at *least* two *trained* people who have 
potential access to every different permission, every different key, 
every different secret. If one person out of two is removed because of 
death, illness, termination of employment (etc.), then another person 
should be *immediately* trained and granted access to maintain the bare 
minimum of two.
2) A caveat to the above: Some things are supposed to be permanently 
"secret", in which case, only one person knowing is acceptable, 
provided that such information or tasks being permanently lost is 
acceptable.
3) The pairs (and/or groups or chains) of "trusted access" should be 
known to the others involved and designated ahead of time. In a 
corporate network, this can be a previously designated SysAdmin taking 
over for the CTO's secrets, and in a personal situation, this would be 
(in my case, for example, referring to my tech work) one of two 
existing "failover Rons" taking responsibility (both are long-term 
friends, both are guru level *nix folks, and both are known to my 
friends and family).
4) Regular rehearsals are pretty much mandatory, to iron out any bugs 
in the policy (and the tech). This is where I've seen things get the 
stickiest, because it's one step people often don't go through (often 
for comfort reasons). Sure, you can say "well, Keith will just take 
over the account", but unless that transition is actually rehearsed a 
few times, *and* kept up to date, folks get into all sorts of snarls. 
Just like in all other forms of disaster recovery, simulating the 
disaster exposes most of the existing flaws.
5) Document *everything*. Under stressful situations, it's far too easy 
to forget what the designated procedures were. The last living will 
"event" in my family was getting pretty ugly, until we went back to 
"the written policy portion" (the living will itself) to re-conform to 
procedure.

Out of the above, some other policies grew. For example, if there are 
only two established and trained root users (be that "root" for a 
machine, a bank account, or even a deed to a house), the two should 
never travel together in the same plane, or otherwise risk a 
catastrophic dual-loss. For some secrets, *every* stakeholder knows 
ahead of time who will assume authority and responsibility, but for 
other secrets, several people are trained for the task, and the actual 
fail over person is unknown until the event itself (such as items kept 
secret in a will, for example). One fairly difficult event involved the 
custody of the documentation itself, as someone was attempting to 
subvert procedure by keeping the procedures themselves unknown.

> In our case, we have socialized with enough PLUG folk that she knows
> people that can help with personal disaster recovery.  But will she
> use them, rather than, say, my Windoze-zealot lawyer brother-in-law?
> These things are best decided in advance, formally, and given that
> any particular person I appoint as a technical successor could move
> or otherwise be unavailable, I would prefer to appoint a trustworthy,
> picked group.

Well... depending on the task involved, appointing a vague group can 
*cause* more headaches than designating a specific chain. Simply look 
at the squabbling of a family without a will, where the children fight 
for control of assets. In the corporate world, similar infighting 
occurs over power and authority. IME, it's far better to have a 
regularly updated "chain" of rehearsed succession.

-Ronabop

Ronin Professional Solutions LLC
4245 NE Alberta Ct.
Portland, OR 97218

From ckonstan at lunarlogic.com  Sun May 29 18:51:47 2005
From: ckonstan at lunarlogic.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 18:51:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Grub with a new kernel
In-Reply-To: <200505291716.32671.michael.harrisdmd@comcast.net>
References: <200505290939.01693.michael.harrisdmd@comcast.net>
	<200505291346.03232.michael.harrisdmd@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0505291409170.7093@localhost>
	<200505291716.32671.michael.harrisdmd@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0505291816460.7093@localhost>

By this, I mean to change a config option from "compiled as a kernel
module" to "compiled into the kernel itself".  In the ncurses-based
menuconfig program (launched by "make menuconfig"), options that are
set to compile as modules have an "M" by them, and pressing "M" is how
you'd set an option to be compiled that way.  What you want to do is
find the appropriate IDE/ATA/SCSI options and hit "Y" by them, thereby
placing a "*" next to them as a visual indicator that they will be
compiled into the bzImage itself.

The appropriate options can be found by running "lspci" and seeing
what your hardware looks like.  For instance, lspci on my Dell
Inspiron 8200 laptop gives me this:

0000:00:00.0 Host bridge: Intel Corp. 82845 845 (Brookdale) Chipset Host Bridge (rev 04)
0000:00:01.0 PCI bridge: Intel Corp. 82845 845 (Brookdale) Chipset AGP Bridge (rev 04)
0000:00:1d.0 USB Controller: Intel Corp. 82801CA/CAM USB (Hub #1) (rev 02)
0000:00:1d.1 USB Controller: Intel Corp. 82801CA/CAM USB (Hub #2) (rev 02)
0000:00:1d.2 USB Controller: Intel Corp. 82801CA/CAM USB (Hub #3) (rev 02)
0000:00:1e.0 PCI bridge: Intel Corp. 82801 PCI Bridge (rev 42)
0000:00:1f.0 ISA bridge: Intel Corp. 82801CAM ISA Bridge (LPC) (rev 02)
0000:00:1f.1 IDE interface: Intel Corp. 82801CAM IDE U100 (rev 02)
0000:00:1f.5 Multimedia audio controller: Intel Corp. 82801CA/CAM AC'97 Audio Controller (rev 02)
0000:00:1f.6 Modem: Intel Corp. 82801CA/CAM AC'97 Modem Controller (rev 02)
0000:01:00.0 VGA compatible controller: nVidia Corporation NV11 [GeForce2 Go] (rev b2)
0000:02:00.0 Ethernet controller: 3Com Corporation 3c905C-TX/TX-M [Tornado] (rev 78)
0000:02:01.0 CardBus bridge: Texas Instruments PCI4451 PC card Cardbus Controller
0000:02:01.1 CardBus bridge: Texas Instruments PCI4451 PC card Cardbus Controller
0000:02:01.2 FireWire (IEEE 1394): Texas Instruments PCI4451 IEEE-1394 Controller
0000:02:08.0 Ethernet controller: 3Com Corporation 3c905C-TX/TX-M [Tornado] (rev 78)

The line I care about if I'm interested in the IDE bus is:

0000:00:1f.1 IDE interface: Intel Corp. 82801CAM IDE U100 (rev 02)

With this info (and the knowledge that I have a CD and a floppy
drive), I know to set up my IDE config like:

<*>   Enhanced IDE/MFM/RLL disk/cdrom/tape/floppy support
---     Please see Documentation/ide.txt for help/info on IDE drives
[ ]     Support for SATA (deprecated; conflicts with libata SATA driver)
[ ]     Use old disk-only driver on primary interface
<*>     Include IDE/ATA-2 DISK support
[ ]       Use multi-mode by default
<*>     PCMCIA IDE support
<M>     Include IDE/ATAPI CDROM support
< >     Include IDE/ATAPI TAPE support (EXPERIMENTAL)
<*>     Include IDE/ATAPI FLOPPY support
<M>     SCSI emulation support
[*]     IDE Taskfile Access
---     IDE chipset support/bugfixes
<*>     generic/default IDE chipset support
[ ]     CMD640 chipset bugfix/support
[ ]     PNP EIDE support
[*]     PCI IDE chipset support
[*]       Sharing PCI IDE interrupts support
[ ]       Boot off-board chipsets first support
<*>       Generic PCI IDE Chipset Support
< >       OPTi 82C621 chipset enhanced support (EXPERIMENTAL)
< >       RZ1000 chipset bugfix/support
[*]       Generic PCI bus-master DMA support
[ ]         Force enable legacy 2.0.X HOSTS to use DMA
[*]         Use PCI DMA by default when available
[ ]           Enable DMA only for disks
< >         AEC62XX chipset support
< >         ALI M15x3 chipset support
< >         AMD and nVidia IDE support
< >         ATI IXP chipset IDE support
< >         CMD64{3|6|8|9} chipset support
< >         Compaq Triflex IDE support
< >         CY82C693 chipset support
< >         Cyrix CS5510/20 MediaGX chipset support (VERY EXPERIMENTAL)
< >         Cyrix/National Semiconductor CS5530 MediaGX chipset support
< >         HPT34X chipset support
< >         HPT36X/37X chipset support
< >         National SCx200 chipset support
<*>         Intel PIIXn chipsets support
< >         NS87415 chipset support
< >         PROMISE PDC202{46|62|65|67} support
< >         PROMISE PDC202{68|69|70|71|75|76|77} support
< >         ServerWorks OSB4/CSB5/CSB6 chipsets support
< >         Silicon Image chipset support
< >         SiS5513 chipset support
< >         SLC90E66 chipset support
< >         Tekram TRM290 chipset support
< >         VIA82CXXX chipset support
[ ]     Other IDE chipset support
[ ]     IGNORE word93 Validation BITS

You'll notice that everything that has to do with the IDE bus is
marked with "<*>".  That's how the kernel can read the hard drive
without needing any modules found in an initrd image.

Carlos

From rich at paranoid.org  Sun May 29 19:23:14 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 19:23:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Death in the open source community
In-Reply-To: <20050529212825.GA19729@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0505271644550.11498@sco302.DavidMandel.com>	<86ll60wkz5.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>	<20050528171002.GA23448@gate.kl-ic.com>	<4298EAEC.7000808@cesmail.net>	<20050529153806.GA4378@gate.kl-ic.com>	<86mzqeug6o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<429A033C.70507@axpr.net>	<429A0F34.8020009@paranoid.org>
	<20050529212825.GA19729@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <429A7912.5020203@paranoid.org>

> Keith responds:
> Rich, you have surely heard of encrypted file systems? 

Of course I have. And I know that having an encrypted filesystem does 
not mean that you can't also have other filesystems which are not encrypted.

Again, if we're talking about an Open Source project, the fact that your 
encrypted filesystem is the only decent copy of the data for the project 
is a problem even from a DR perspective.

> Now, pretend I get hit by a bus - or I'm visiting Athlon Rob, and I'm
> hit by a log truck or tractor.  My wife is smart enough to spend two
> years learning to be a sysadmin and run my servers after me, but
> chances are she has a few other things to worry about.  What happens
> with my computers?  My offsite colo?  Who moderates the mailing
> lists?  Who does what I used to do?  At very bare minimum, who does
> she trust to transition the systems and data to other maintainers? 
> She, at least, has met some of you folks.  But which of you should
> she trust, and how should she decide that?

Those are all things you would certainly want to arrange in advance, so 
she wouldn't need to decide. You would want to have all of that spelled 
out in your will. If you haven't done that then you definitely should.

> This is why I would like to work with a group of similarly concerned
> individuals to design such a process, systematically.  More heads are
> better than fewer, and when the process is tested, it will improve as
> the survivors gain experience.

By all means go for it. I'm not sure the PLUG list is the best place to 
work out the details of that, perhaps you could set up a dedicated list 
for your project and notify people here how to join if they wish.

 > Rich, if you read what I wrote carefully, you will notice that I did
 > not accuse you of lacking empathy or compassion.

I didn't think it was directed at me individually, but you did say, "Now 
it might be that most people don't give a shit what happens to others 
after they pass away..."

I don't know why you would say that. I'm guessing that most people here 
do give a shit, but you seemed to imply that those who were not eager to 
join in your project fit that category. I think that was a bit of a 
cheap shot and in poor taste. Someone can be empathetic and have 
compassion and still think you are making what should be a fairly simple 
issue more complex than it needs to be.

If you are talking about an Open Source project, make sure to share your 
data with your team members and keep offsite backups. If you are talking 
about personal data, definitely make arrangements for the people who 
need access to it to be able to recover it. If you think the best way to 
do that is to share pieces of your keys with other people then do that. 
It's not exactly a new concept, as you mentioned.


Rich

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael D Harris <michael.harrisdmd at comcast.net> writes:

Michael> By the way, how would I go about getting the
Michael> module-init-tools using apt-get?

Michael> My current settings and apt-sources are set to keep my Debian
Michael> Sarge up to date.

I don't know who Sarge is.  Sarge is a code name and I refused to sign
the NDA, so they won't tell me ;-).  On a "stable" box,
module-init-tools isn't available.  On a "testing" box,
module-init-tools is available.  

  # apt-get install module-init-tools

You can have both the old and new module tools (modutils) installed at
the same time.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue May 31 10:35:31 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 10:35:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mailman and spamassassin
Message-ID: <20050531173531.GB13324@gate.kl-ic.com>


I run a few Mailman groups set up for subscriber-only posting.
That means that any incoming spam gets sent to the moderator (me)
for approval or discard.  In the past, this has not been a problem,
with all the other checks that are in place.

However, the spams are starting to sneak through, and some time in
the future I may have to add filtering so I am not bombarded with 
moderator messages.  I would like to filter the moderator requests
only;  mail from legitimate subscribers should go through unhindered.

I know how to add spamassassin as a procmail prefilter for Mailman;
is there some clever way to use it on moderator requests only?  Since
the filtering needs to occur inside Mailman, and since there are plenty
of legitimate mails that should pass through to the moderator, I imagine
the answer is "no".  However, there are some smart people here...

Keith

From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue May 31 12:02:41 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 12:02:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mailman and spamassassin
In-Reply-To: <20050531173531.GB13324@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050531173531.GB13324@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <20050531190240.GB20412@bavariati.org>

On Tue, May 31, 2005 at 10:35:31AM -0700, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> I know how to add spamassassin as a procmail prefilter for Mailman;
> is there some clever way to use it on moderator requests only?  Since
> the filtering needs to occur inside Mailman, and since there are plenty
> of legitimate mails that should pass through to the moderator, I imagine
> the answer is "no".  However, there are some smart people here...

Moderator requests are basically personal email, right?  Me, I filter
out mailing-list traffic with procmail, then run SA only on personal
emails.  (Mail server is a UML session *barely* powerful enough to run SA.)
I first flag, then filter spam like so:
	:0fw: spamassassin.lock
	* < 256000
	| spamassassin
 
	:0:
	* ^X-Spam-Status:.Yes
	spam.sa/

If your moderator requests are being jumbled in with the regular list
traffic, you'll have to explain to procmail that they're actually not.
Or you could do something like the above, earlier in your .procmailrc,
with a filter to apply it only to moderator messages.

Oh, and good on yer for moderating a list.  It's a lot of work, and
it's never appreciated enough by the many beneficiaries.

From wamorita at hevanet.com  Tue May 31 15:35:08 2005

Group,

I have put into /etc/fstab the line:

//server/datashare  /share smbfs   username=guest,rw  0 0

While this does mount the volume, the result is that non-root accounts do
not have read/write access.

Read/write access for non-root is present if mounted manually using the
command:

smbmount //server/datashare /share rw -o guest


So what did I miss ?

From wamorita at hevanet.com  Tue May 31 16:03:05 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 16:03:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] smbmount Queestion continued
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0505311540020.8741@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200505312303.j4VN36624839@pop.hevanet.com>

Richard,

Tried that, no help.  The problem is two fold,
  1.  The "username=guest" is a documented smbmount option to suppress the
password requirement.  E.g. when I mount using a "mount -a"
  2.  The "rw" needs to be extended past root.  The "guest" designation is
supposed to do this.  Leaving it out the smbmount is done with the user as
"root". 

There must be a special form for these arguments in /etc/fstab, but I have
not found them in the documentation.

- Bill 
wamorita at hevanet.com

From ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net  Tue May 31 16:08:31 2005
From: ewilhelm at sbcglobal.net (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 16:08:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] smbmount Queestion continued
In-Reply-To: <200505312235.j4VMZA607042@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <200505312235.j4VMZA607042@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <200505311608.31637.ewilhelm@sbcglobal.net>

# The following was supposedly scribed by
# William A Morita
# on Tuesday 31 May 2005 03:35 pm:

>//server/datashare ?/share smbfs ? username=guest,rw ?0 0
>
>smbmount //server/datashare /share rw -o guest

nit:  -o username=guest makes the above two equivelant

>While this does mount the volume, the result is that non-root accounts
> do not have read/write access.

The trouble with samba is that it is designed to be mounted and used by 
one user per system (e.g. as is the case in some single-user OS.)  
Thus, the user that mounts the share will own everything on it, and the 
username that it is mounted as will own everything that you create 
while it's mounted.

I always mount my samba shares under my home directory.  If you want 
multiple users using a samba share, either you need to mount multiple 
times (preferred), or chmod 777 everything on the share (or do 
something fun with groups.)

--Eric

From raanders at acm.org  Tue May 31 16:10:40 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 16:10:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] smbmount Queestion continued
In-Reply-To: <200505312235.j4VMZA607042@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0505311552110.4280-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 31 May 2005, William A Morita wrote:

> Group,
> 
> I have put into /etc/fstab the line:
> 
> //server/datashare  /share smbfs   username=guest,rw  0 0
> 
> While this does mount the volume, the result is that non-root accounts do
> not have read/write access.

What are the permissions on /share?  Who are the user and group? What are
the permissions of //server/datashare on the Windows system?  Is there a 
guest id ( with no password ) on the Windows system?

So after all those questions I'll supply some settings that ahve worked 
for me ( YMMV ).

in /etc/fstab

//server/datashare /mount/point smbfs credentials=/etc/samba/datashare,port=44

in /etc/samba/datashare

username=joeblow
password=xyzzy

/mount/point is joeblow:joeblow ug=rwx

The documentation indicates you may be able to set the group on
/mount/point to "users" and put all your users in that group and add an
option the gid=users to the fstab entry.


Rod

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue May 31 16:17:12 2005

Subject: [PLUG] mdadm raid1 creation stomped on jfs superblock?
Message-ID: <86ll5vrnnr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


In the process of recovering my rsync snapshots, I ended up with a
surplus of 200 gig disks.  My intention is to build a raid1 array to
store one of the snapshot trees with two extra disks.  I had hoped to
take an existing filesystem (and a dd'd copy) and transform it into a
raid1 array.  I did the "mdadm --create" [1] and mounted it read-only
with no hiccups.  However, when I boot, I get this message during the
fsck:

   The current drive is:  /dev/md1

   Superblock is corrupt and cannot be repaired
   since both primary and secondary copies are corrupt.

     CANNOT CONTINUE

   fsck failed.  Please repair manually.

I assume [??] this is because mdadm stomped on jfs somehow that jfs
doesn't like[2].  Do I have to re-mkfs and then rebuild the snapshot
tree from another backup or is there something simpler I can do?  I'd
ordinarily have done it in the Right Order[tm], but building the
snapshot trees is tedious.  Hell, just dd'ing disk to disk takes about
3 hours.  Clues?

Thanks!

[1] Like so:

    # mdadm --create /dev/md1 --auto=yes --level=1 --raid-devices=2 /dev/hdm1 /dev/hdp1

[2] Strace'ing the fsck.jfs, I see to looking at two locations (32768
    and 61440) and doing 4k reads immediately prior to the "is
    corrupt" message.

>While this does mount the volume, the result is that non-root accounts  
>do not have read/write access.

The trouble with samba is that it is designed to be mounted and used by one
user per system (e.g. as is the case in some single-user OS.) Thus, the user
that mounts the share will own everything on it, and the username that it is
mounted as will own everything that you create while it's mounted.

I always mount my samba shares under my home directory.  If you want
multiple users using a samba share, either you need to mount multiple times
(preferred), or chmod 777 everything on the share (or do something fun with
groups.)

--Eric
--

From jason at vancleve.com  Tue May 31 16:42:04 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)

Subject: [PLUG] smbmount Queestion continued

Message-ID: <20050531164204.5f37d725.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth William A Morita, on Tue, 31 May 2005 15:35:08 -0700:

> While this does mount the volume, the result is that non-root accounts
> do not have read/write access.

Couple of quasi-random ideas.  First, change the owner/group of the
mount point, BEFORE mounting it, to the user as whom you'll be accessing
the mount.  I've had problems where I couldn't write to the mount as a
normal user even when ls showed me as that owner of writable files, and
I had to umount, chmod the mount point to myself and then remount it. 
Samba's paranoid in that respect.

Second, try playing with the gid and uid options in fstab.

HTH,

--Jason V. C.

	writeable = yes
	guest ok = Yes

username=joeblow
password=xyzzy

/mount/point is joeblow:joeblow ug=rwx

On Tue, 31 May 2005, William A Morita wrote:

> My mount point /share is:
> drwxr-xr-x  1 root root 4096 May 31 16:37 /share

Bill,

   The only person who can modify or delete files in /share is root. You need
to give the world/others write permissions to the directory and its files.

   "... If a directory has read permission you can see what files are in the
directory (using the ls command without arguments or options), write
permission to a directory means you can add, remove or rename files in the
directory (providing you have the permission to cd into that directory).
Execute permission (also called the "search bit") allow you to use the
directory name when accessing files inside that directory (to cd into the
directory)."
