From fpikus at gmail.com  Tue May 31 18:09:27 2005
From: fpikus at gmail.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 18:09:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mdadm raid1 creation stomped on jfs superblock?
In-Reply-To: <86ll5vrnnr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86ll5vrnnr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <a4fbdc7b05053118095b4f5f9@mail.gmail.com>

On 31 May 2005 16:17:12 -0700, Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> wrote:
> 
> In the process of recovering my rsync snapshots, I ended up with a
> surplus of 200 gig disks.  My intention is to build a raid1 array to
> store one of the snapshot trees with two extra disks.  I had hoped to
> take an existing filesystem (and a dd'd copy) and transform it into a
> raid1 array.

At this point you can pretty much kiss your filesystem goodbye. Raid
takes up a bit of space at the beginning of the partition, for raid
superblocks, so your filesystem is hosed.

The proper procedure for converting a filesystem to a mirror raid is this:

1) Say, you have /dev/hda1 and you want to make it a mirror with
/dev/hdb1. You create the RAID in degraded mode,

mdadm --create /dev/md0 --level=1 --raid-devices=2 /dev/hdb1 missing

2) Now you create filesystem on /dev/md0, you will notice that its
size is slightly less than what you have on hda1.

3) Copy data from hda1 to md0.

4) Change partition type of hda1 to fd and hotadd it to the array:
mdadm --add /dev/md0 /dev/hda1
The array will reconstruct.

The above procedure suggests your only chance to recover the data:

1) Stop the array
2) Try to mount one disk, preferably the original, as the separate
filesystem. If that fails, try to fsck it.
3) If this works, you're in luck, do the steps above. If it fails,
you're hosed. The success will depend on what exactly jfs stores in
the first few bytes and whether fsck can reconstruct it.


> I did the "mdadm --create" [1] and mounted it read-only
> with no hiccups.  However, when I boot, I get this message during the
> fsck:
> 
>    The current drive is:  /dev/md1
> 
>    Superblock is corrupt and cannot be repaired
>    since both primary and secondary copies are corrupt.
> 
>      CANNOT CONTINUE
> 
>    fsck failed.  Please repair manually.
> 
> I assume [??] this is because mdadm stomped on jfs somehow that jfs
> doesn't like[2].  Do I have to re-mkfs and then rebuild the snapshot
> tree from another backup or is there something simpler I can do?  I'd
> ordinarily have done it in the Right Order[tm], but building the
> snapshot trees is tedious.  Hell, just dd'ing disk to disk takes about
> 3 hours.  Clues?
> 
> Thanks!
>

>

>     and 61440) and doing 4k reads immediately prior to the "is
>     corrupt" message.

From wamorita at hevanet.com  Tue May 31 20:27:51 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 20:27:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] X Window System Configuration -- SOLVED! (A second
	solution)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0505311920050.24757@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200506010327.j513RrZ71399@pop.hevanet.com>

Rich,

You might try using an .Xdefaults file in your home directory.
Examining and old one I have there is the pertinate section:

*xterm*Font: 9x15
*xterm*background: black
*xterm*borderColor: blue
*xterm*cursorColor: red
*xterm*foreground: white
*xterm*loginShell: true
*xterm*scrollBar: true
*xterm*saveLines: 150
*xterm*visualBell: false
*xterm*bellVolume: 44
*xterm*bellPitch: 0
*xterm*bellDuration: 55
*xterm*ttyModes:  intr ^? quit ^| erase ^h kill ^g eof ^d eol ^` start ^q
stop ^s susp ^~ swtch ^`

The foreground and background lines are the equivalent of the -fg and -bg
command line switches.  The .Xdefaults file resides in your home directory,
thus you could have a differing background color for each login if you
wanted.

If you want more detail on the keywords used, it should be in the help for
xterm.

- Bill Morita
wamorita at hevanet.com

Let me chime in here. You can install *most* of the Gentoo Reference
Platform from binaries on an i386. You can also install *most* of the
Gentoo Reference Platform from binaries on an i686, athlon-xp, pentium3
or pentium4. *However*, some of the initial packages in the install do
get compiled -- they're fairly small.

In addition, your *updates* will be recompiled; as far as I know there's
no binary package repository. If you need regular updates and can't
handle the compile times, you might be better off with Debian. Sarge is
coming out in a couple of weeks, and they've got something like 16,000
packages to choose from. Gentoo is close to 10,000, but again, anything
that isn't in the Gentoo Reference Package will need to be recompiled.

Rich Burroughs wrote:

> Michael H. Collins wrote:
>
>>
>> binaries are already built.
>
>

> to building it from source.

> that up.

> Fedor> The proper procedure for converting a filesystem to a mirror
> Fedor> raid is this:
> 
> Fedor> 1) Say, you have /dev/hda1 and you want to make it a mirror
> Fedor> with /dev/hdb1. You create the RAID in degraded mode,
> 
> Fedor> mdadm --create /dev/md0 --level=1 --raid-devices=2 /dev/hdb1
> Fedor> missing
> 
> Fedor> 2) Now you create filesystem on /dev/md0, you will notice that
> Fedor> its size is slightly less than what you have on hda1.
> 
> Fedor> 3) Copy data from hda1 to md0.
> 
> What do you mean by "copy" there?

mount hda1, mount md0, copy data using tar or cp -a or however you like.

That's what I thought.  

With these rsync snapshots, in order to keep the hardlink data from
exploding (there are a *lot* of hard links!), you need to essentially
replay the snapshot creations, which is easy enough.  You build a
script and then play the script and everything gets recreated.

For example, suppose that you are serving the domain www.domain.tld and 
you wish to add the virtual host www.otherdomain.tld, which points at 
the same IP address. Then you simply add the following to httpd.conf:

NameVirtualHost *:80

<VirtualHost *:80>
ServerName www.domain.tld
ServerAlias domain.tld *.domain.tld
DocumentRoot /www/domain
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:80>
ServerName www.otherdomain.tld
DocumentRoot /www/otherdomain
</VirtualHost>
